response_text: Mercury(II) perchlorate is an inorganic chemical compound with the formula Hg(ClO4)2·nH2O, where n can range from 0 to 6. The anhydrous and hydrates are all toxic, water-soluble, and hygroscopic white solids. == Preparation and reactions == Hydrates of mercury(II) perchlorate are most commonly prepared by the reaction of mercury(II) oxide and concentrated perchloric acid: HgO + 2 HClO4 → Hg(ClO4)2 + H2O Evaporation of the resulting solution results in the formation of the hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, which can be converted to lower hydrates, such as the dihydrate, by heating to 30 °C in a vacuum. Further heating does not produce the anhydrous form, but instead forms a basic mercury perchlorate. The anhydrous form is produced by dehydrating the dihydrate with anhydrous perchloric acid or dichlorine hexoxide. Solutions of mercury(II) perchlorate in water reacts with aqueous ammonia to produce tetraamminemercury(II) perchlorate, [Hg(NH3)4](ClO4)2. Heating of the tetraammine complex results in the diammine complex. Mercury(II) perchlorate also reacts with elemental mercury to form mercury(I) perchlorate: Hg(ClO4)2 + Hg → Hg2(ClO4)2 == Structure == The solid hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, has a trigonal crystal structure and consists of octahederal [Hg(H2O)6]2+ centers and ClO4– ions. The anhydrous form was probed by IR spectroscopy and was found to consist of monodendate perchlorate ions. == Applications == Mercury(II) perchlorate finds limited applications in organic synthesis, such as in the hydrolysis of vinyl halides and the allylation of isatins and isatin ketoimines. == References ==

response_text:
Humboldthain is a public park in the Berlin-Mitte district. The park was established in 1869 on a site that was formerly occupied by a cemetery. The 33.4 hectare (82.5 acre) green space is characterized by two distinctive hills which rise approximately 78 metres (256 feet) above the surrounding terrain.

== History ==
The park was designed in 1869 by the renowned Berlin landscape architect Gustav Meyer. The Humboldthain had been used as a cemetery until 1888. After the cemetery was closed, the area began its development into a public park. Two large artificial hills were created from the leftover soil and rubble. These hills provide a striking landscape feature in the otherwise relatively flat terrain of northern Berlin.

After the end of World War I, the park gained a flak tower (Flakturm) on its southern hill to provide defense against Allied air raids during World War II. After the war, the flak tower was partially demolished, but sections of the structure remain visible today.

During the Cold War, the park was directly adjacent to the Berlin Wall. The wall has since been removed.

== Facilities ==
The park offers multiple facilities and attractions:

Café-Restaurant: Located on the southern hill with views overlooking the park.
Veranstaltungsort: An event venue; renovation was completed in 2014. The Kulturbrauerei collective opened the venue with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns.

== Conservation ==
The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte.

== Access ==
The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes.

== Gallery ==

== References ==

Humboldthain is a public park in the Gesundbrunnen district of Berlin-Mitte, in the state of Berlin, Germany. The park incorporates the remains of two World War II anti-aircraft gun towers (flak towers) and two of their associated protective walls, which have been preserved as historic monuments. The site was known during the Cold War as one of West Berlin's most distinctive landmarks.

== History ==
The two flak towers and their protective walls were built during World War II to protect the city's power station and railway junction from Allied bombing. After the war, the site's prominent position and the presence of the anti-aircraft towers made it a landmark for all of Berlin. Following the division of the city during the Cold War, the towers became a distinctive feature of West Berlin. After reunification, the site was developed as a public park. The park officially opened to the public in 2004, with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May.

== Facilities ==
The park contains the following facilities:

Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. response_text:
Humboldthain is a public park in the Gesundbrunnen district of Berlin in the northern part of Mitte. The park is 33 hectares (82 acres) in area. It incorporates two artificial hills, with the higher one reaching 78 meters (256 ft) above the surrounding terrain.

== History ==

The park was developed between 1869 and 1876 on the site of the Humboldt Brewery. In 1942-43 and 1943-44, two large flak towers (anti-aircraft defense structures) were built in the park during World War II. After the war, the site was transformed into a park. It was redeveloped into its current form in 1987, and has developed into an important recreation and cultural venue within Mitte. 

On 10 May 2019, the "Gelände Funktion" (Site Function) opened at the location as a creative space. The venue was created in collaboration with street artists and designers. It hosts events such as club nights, art exhibitions and concerts, with groups playing at the outdoor stage during summer weekends. In 2021, the venue underwent significant renovation and relaunched with a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

response_text:
June & John

June & John is a 2024 science fiction romantic film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Jessie Buckley and Timothée Chalamet as the title characters June and John.

Plot

The film follows two young people, June and John, who meet in a near-future world where artificial intelligence has become an integral part of daily life. They fall in love while navigating a society where human connection has become increasingly mediated by technology. Their relationship becomes a metaphor for authenticity in a digitalized world.

Production

The film was shot using advanced virtual cinematography techniques and AI-assisted color grading. Besson employed innovative deepfake technology for several sequences, marking a significant shift toward machine learning in his filmmaking approach.

Reception

Critics had mixed reactions to the film. Variety praised its visual innovation but criticized its shallow narrative. The Hollywood Reporter noted: "While 'June & John' impresses with its technical ambition, it struggles to find emotional depth beneath its polished surface."

Le Figaro's review stated: "What ultimately holds back 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==

June and John at IMDb

She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. Their pale blue eyes and pale skinned appearance made them stand out in their rural community, where they toiled from an early age in the tobacco fields. == Abduction == In 1899 when Willie was nine and George was just six years old they were discovered by a "freak-hunter" called James Herman "Candy" Shelton. response_text: Linda Keren Godfrey is a South African engineer and Principal Scientist at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in South Africa. Polyps are arranged along branches, featuring eight tentacles with pinnules. Colony coloration ranges from pale yellow to brown, with a maximum recorded height of approximately 60 centimeters. Its skeletal composition includes gorgonin and calcite, providing structural support. Compared to congeners, I. chewbacca exhibits more densely packed branches, contributing to its rarity in surveys. Iridogorgia spans the Pacific and Atlantic, but I. chewbacca appears endemic to the western Pacific hotspot. response_text:
# Charles Carshon

Charles Carshon (1920–2011) was an American actor and director who maintained a 60-year career in theatre, spanning Broadway, Off-Broadway, regional theatre, and dramatic arts education.

== Career ==

=== Acting ===

Carshon began his professional theatre career in the 1940s, appearing in Broadway productions and in numerous Off-Broadway and regional theatre productions throughout his career. His Broadway credits include The Tower Beyond Tragedy (1950) and Billy Budd (1951).

=== Directing ===

As a director, Carshon co-founded Tapestry Theatre in New York and, with his wife, the Green Gate Theatre company at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, New York. For more than 35 years at Sarah Lawrence College's theatre program, Carshon served as director and mentor. Working within the college's Department of Theatre for 35 years, he directed student and resident company productions and mentored generations of actors. In the late 1970s, the Carshons' resident company Green Gate Theatre presented Harold Pinter's Old Times as part of the college's "Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence" series, under Charles and Gloria's direction.

== Teaching ==

Beyond Sarah Lawrence, Carshon taught at New York City's High School of Performing Arts, the Stella Adler Studio, the Neighborhood Playhouse, and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His obituary notes that "many famous actors passed through his classes."

== Stage credits (selected) ==

Broadway
The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov 26–Dec 22, 1950) — The Queen's Slave (cast).
Billy Budd (Feb 10–May 12, 1951) — company member (replacement).

Off-Broadway
Beethoven/Karl (1975) — performer.

== Personal life ==

Carshon married actress and producer Gloria Barret. They frequently collaborated on productions connected to Sarah Lawrence College, including projects with the Green Gate Theatre company. In 1948, Carshon resided at 444 East 58th Street, Manhattan (Sutton Place).

== Death ==

Carshon died on October 28, 2011, at the age of 91. He was survived by his wife, Gloria Barret.

== Legacy ==

Carshon's blended career—as a working actor/director and a long-tenured teacher/mentor—made him a fixture of New York's mid-century theatre training ecosystem and a contributor to the growth of Off-Broadway ensembles such as Tapestry Theatre and Green Gate Theatre.

== References ==

== External links ==

Charles Carshon at BroadwayWorld

Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

response_text: The Muse brothers were four African-American men born with albinism who rose to fame for being displayed in a circus during the early 20th century. The brothers became well known for being exhibited as circus freaks at Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus. The brothers' names were Willie, George, Ike, and Benjaman. Willie was the oldest brother, born in 1892. George was born in 1891, Ike in 1893, and Benjaman in 1895. The brothers' story is one of exploitation and triumph over adversity. In 1912, the brothers were kidnapped by circus promoter R.W. Gaskill, who promised their parents that they would receive an education and a share of circus profits. However, the brothers were instead forced to perform in the circus without receiving their promised wages. After years of performing in the circus, the brothers eventually ran away and sought legal action against the circus. In 1927, the brothers won their case and came to a settlement where the circus agree to pay back the brothers wages. The brothers were also offered a deal to return to the circus where a portion of their salary would be paid to their parents and their younger brother Tom (who also exhibited albinism) would be given employment. George died in 1971 at the age of 80 years old, while Willie died in 2001 aged 108. == Family == The Muse brothers' parents were Cabell Muse and Harriet Muse, who were both descendants of former slaves. After the kidnapping of the brothers, their mother would go on to have three more children named Tom, Annie Belle and Harrison. All five of the mother's children were born with albinism. Multiple other members of the Muse family also exhibited albinism including uncles and a niece. == References ==

# I Don't Know How

**I Don't Know How** is the debut studio album by Scottish singer-songwriter Fran McRae. It was released on 4 March 2022 through Domino Recording Company. The album marks McRae's first full-length project following the release of two EPs: *Spare* (2018) and *Dinner* (2019).

== Background ==
McRae worked with producer Dan Carey on the album, known for his work with artists including Bat for Lashes and Prop. Recording took place across multiple locations including London, Berlin and the Scottish Highlands. The album was largely recorded during the COVID-19 pandemic, which informed some of its themes.

response_text:
# Live Long and Prosper

Live Long and Prosper is a Chinese drama series starring Dylan Wang, Li Qin, and Rong Zishan. The series is based on a xianxia web novel and is produced by Hunan Satellite TV and Mango TV.

== Plot ==
The story follows Song Qianji, a powerful immortal who was consumed by his ambition, competitiveness, and arrogance who exhausted himself in ceaseless rivalry. Granted a second chance at life and armed with prior knowledge, he resolves to drift through existence as a carefree 'salted fish' (a euphemism for someone who wishes to 'lie flat'), adopting a detached outlook and devoting much of his energy to tending his crops. Yet, by chance, he gathers a circle of steadfast companions and is unwillingly drawn into sectarian conflict. In the end, to protect the land and people he cherishes, he reluctantly returns to cultivation (advancing through successive levels of strength and facing heavenly tribulations), leading his comrades to shoulder the burden of salvation through his very being.

== Cast ==

=== Main cast ===
Dylan Wang as Song Qianji
Li Qin as Miao Yan
Rong Zishan as Meng Heze

=== Supporting cast ===
Wang Duo as Wei Zhenyu
Zhang Yaqin as He Qingqing
Xia Meng as Chen Hongzhu
Tong Mengshi as Ziye Wenshu
Wu Xize as Yuan Qingshi
Ye Shengjia as Ji Chen

== Production ==
Production for the series began in Hengdian World Studios in late April, with the series officially announced in mid-May at the Hunan Satellite TV & Mango TV industry conference. Production moved to Xinjiang in August and filming is complete as of 26 September 2025.

== References ==

== External links ==
Live Long and Prosper at IMDb
Live Long and Prosper at Douban (in Chinese)
Live Long and Prosper on Weibo (in Chinese)

response_text: Luc Besson returns to filmmaking with a short work entitled 'June & John', a 12-minute film shot in AI-assisted digital cinematography that premiered at the Cannes Film Festival in May 2024. The film stars Léa Seydoux as June, a free-spirited woman who meets John (played by newcomer actor James Martinez) on a crowded train. What follows is a whimsical, impressionistic portrait of a chance encounter that blossoms into unexpected intimacy. Besson employs cutting-edge technology developed in collaboration with tech company UnReal Engine to create dreamlike visuals filled with saturated colors and soft-focus sequences. The narrative is deliberately fragmented, favoring mood and aesthetic over conventional storytelling. June and John barely exchange meaningful dialogue; instead, their connection unfolds through glances, gestures, and the film's lush visual language. Critics have had mixed reactions to the project. Some praised Besson's technical ambitions and the film's visual poetry. Others felt the work prioritized style over substance. Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote a particularly critical review, noting: "What ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

The species was described in 2025 by Y. Xu, L. Watling, Z. Zhan, and K. Xu in a study analyzing 12 Pacific specimens using morphology and molecular data. It was differentiated from similar species like I. laevis by branch flexibility and polyp arrangement. The name "chewbacca" honors the Star Wars character for the colony's furry silhouette, a practice common in taxonomy to aid memorability. No subspecies are recognized. == Discovery == Specimens of I. chewbacca were first documented in 2006 during a remotely operated vehicle (ROV) survey off Molokaʻi, Hawaii, by the Hawaii Undersea Research Laboratory. A second sighting occurred in 2016 near the Mariana Trench during NOAA's Deepwater Exploration of the Marianas expedition, captured in archival footage. Watling identified the distinct traits while reviewing footage years later. The 2025 Zootaxa paper formalized the description, co-authored with Chinese researchers, using genetic sequencing and morphological analysis of preserved samples. The discovery highlighted ongoing biodiversity in explored regions, with Watling noting the "unforgettable" resemblance to Chewbacca. == Distribution and habitat == Iridogorgia chewbacca resides in the tropical western Pacific Ocean, documented off Hawaii (Molokaʻi) and near the Mariana Trench at depths of 400–1,000 meters on rocky bottoms. response_text: Charles Carshon (c. 1920 – October 28, 2011) was an American actor, theatre director, and acting teacher. A veteran of Broadway and Off-Broadway, he taught at several New York City conservatories and for 35 years headed the Studio Theatre at Sarah Lawrence College. The New York Times obituary called him an "actor, director, teacher, [and] Off-Broadway pioneer." == Career == Carshon's early stage credits included two Broadway productions: The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov–Dec 1950) and Billy Budd (Feb–May 1951). By the mid-1950s he was active Off-Broadway, heading his own company, the Tapestry Theatre. He later performed in the 1975 Off-Broadway production Beethoven/Karl and collaborated frequently with his wife, Gloria Barret Carshon. Carshon was also closely associated with Sarah Lawrence College for decades. As head of the college's Studio Theatre for 35 years, he directed student and resident company productions and mentored generations of actors. In the late 1970s, the Carshons' resident company Green Gate Theatre presented Harold Pinter's Old Times as part of the college's "Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence" series, under Charles and Gloria's direction. == Teaching == Beyond Sarah Lawrence, Carshon taught at New York City's High School of Performing Arts, the Stella Adler Studio, the Neighborhood Playhouse, and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His obituary notes that "many famous actors passed through his classes." == Stage credits (selected) == Broadway The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov 26–Dec 22, 1950) — The Queen's Slave (cast). Billy Budd (Feb 10–May 12, 1951) — company member (replacement). Off-Broadway Beethoven/Karl (1975) — performer. == Personal life ==

response_text: I Don't Know How is the fourth studio album by American country artist Caroline Spence. It was released on February 3, 2023, through Rounder Records. The album was produced by Jack Antonoff, alongside other producers including Gordie Sampson, Nathan Chapman and Sounwave. The album received generally positive reviews from critics. Paste Magazine gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

response_text: Linda Keren Godfrey is a South African engineer and Principal Scientist at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in South Africa. She is a specialist in the circular economy. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Early life and education == Godfrey studied chemistry at Rhodes University. She earned a Master's in hydrogeology at the University of the Free State. Godfrey earned her doctorate in engineering at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, where she studied waste data. == Research and career == Godfrey manages Circular Innovation South Africa, a programme that looks to move the country to a more circular and sustainable economy. She has argued that half of climate impacts and most biodiversity loss comes from the extraction and processing of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Publications == Winnie W Y Lau; Yonathan Shiran; Richard

Iridogorgia chewbacca

Iridogorgia chewbacca, commonly known as Chewbacca coral, is a rare deep-sea octocoral of the family Iridogorgiidae. Discovered in 2020 during an exploration of seamounts in the western Pacific near Hawaii and the Mariana Trench, it was formally described in 2021. The species epithet honors the Star Wars character Chewbacca, reflecting the distinctive hair-like appearance of its polyps.

== Description ==
I. chewbacca forms branching colonies up to 1 meter tall, characterized by densely packed polyps with long tentacles resembling fur. Coloration ranges from pale yellow to orange-brown. The polyps' hair-like appearance inspired its colloquial name. Skeletal elements include sclerites typical of Iridogorgia, with crystalline structures that may reflect bioluminescence. Colonies attach to hard substrates via a holdfast, anchoring at depths of 600–2,500 meters.

== Habitat and distribution ==
Found in the North Pacific, particularly near Hawaii (Papahānaumokuākea region) and the Mariana Trench, I. chewbacca inhabits oxygen minimum zones and oligotrophic (nutrient-poor) waters. It prefers seamount slopes and trench walls where currents concentrate suspended organic matter, contributing to its rarity in surveys. Iridogorgia spans the Pacific and Atlantic, but I. chewbacca appears endemic to the western Pacific hotspot. Potential range extension awaits further ROV explorations in seamounts and trenches.

== Ecology ==
As a suspension feeder, I. chewbacca relies on polyps to capture plankton and organic detritus from deep currents. Its flexible branches maximize particle encounter in low-flow environments. Colonies host microbial communities and may shelter small invertebrates, though specific symbionts have not been studied. Growth is slow, potentially spanning centuries, as seen in related Iridogorgia species up to 500 years old. Reproduction likely involves fragmentation and spawning, typical of octocorals, but details for I. chewbacca are unspecified. It contributes to deep-sea biodiversity by stabilizing sediments and providing microhabitats.

== Conservation ==
Deep-sea corals (I. chewbacca) face threats from ocean acidification, warming, and deep-sea mining, which disrupt habitats. Its rarity and slow growth heighten vulnerability, though no specific IUCN status has been adopted. Protected areas like Papahānaumokuākea Marine National Monument encompass potential sites. Ongoing research emphasizes non-invasive surveys to monitor populations. The discovery underscores the need for expanded deep-sea conservation amid climate change.

== Cultural significance ==
The naming of I. chewbacca exemplifies pop culture's role in taxonomy, enhancing public engagement with science. Media coverage has boosted awareness of deep-sea biodiversity.

== References ==

The cephalothorax has a blackish eye field with washed-out yellowish submarginal bands that show four white hair spots when dry. It has a pale yellow, whitish hairy median band at front and rear that is tapered and spindle-shaped, showing two pale dark long streaks in front of the striae. The abdomen is dorsally blackish, with a median, pale hairy, black-trimmed lancet band in front. Behind this are four slightly dark median angular spots accompanied on each side by a row of four white hair spots visible only when dry. Ventrally, the sternum is uniformly black, with coxae lighter brown and remaining leg segments whitish hairy, though the posterior metatarsi and tarsi are darkened. == Conservation == The species remains undersampled with a limited known range. More sampling is needed to determine the full geographic range. == Etymology == The species is named after Port Nolloth in the Northern Cape, where the type specimen was collected. == References ==

response_text: GJ 1289 is a red dwarf star located approximately 27 light-years from the Sun in the constellation Andromeda. It is a single star of spectral class M4.5 V, with about 21% of the Sun's mass. The star hosts at least one confirmed exoplanet, GJ 1289 b, and is fully convective, making it a target for studying planetary formation around low-mass stars. Despite its slow rotation, GJ 1289 exhibits large-scale magnetic field strengths similar to those of faster-rotating M dwarfs, suggesting that the star operates a dynamo process in a regime distinct from more rapidly rotating stars. The star is predominantly poloidal with its magnetic topology varying over time, and their small-scale fields contribute more than 70% of the star's overall magnetic flux. == References ==

response_text: 'June & John' is an ambitious film directed by Luc Besson that attempts to explore the nature of love through a blend of live-action and artificial intelligence-generated imagery. The film follows two young protagonists, June and John, as they navigate the complexities of modern romance in a visually stunning but emotionally hollow world. The narrative takes the form of a poetic journey through various landscapes, both real and digitally created, as the characters grapple with their feelings for one another. Critics have noted that while the film's visual presentation is undeniably impressive, its emotional core remains underdeveloped. Le Parisien's review suggests that what ultimately undermines 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

response_text:
Mikako of Kii (紀伊の宮貴子, 1846 – July 9, 1894) was a Japanese noblewoman who became the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and final shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1846 as the daughter of Prince Arisugawanomiya Takahito. She became engaged to Tokugawa Yoshinobu in 1862, marrying him when he was the daimyō of Mito Domain. The couple lived together in Mito, however the union was turbulent as a result of her family dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835, the daughter of Makino Tadakuni, a prominent daimyo and senior councilor (rōjū) to the shōgun. At the age of fifteen, Mikako was married to Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the future shōgun.

== Married life ==
The couple were not close and were unable to have children of their own. According to legend, the two were deeply grieved and it is rumoured that both turned to alcohol as a form of escapism. Many scholars attribute their depression to the loss of their children - the couple had several children, but all were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. 

After the Meiji Restoration, Mikako's life took a dramatic turn. Yoshinobu was placed under house arrest, completely separating the couple. When he was finally released in 1869, he established a new residence, marking a significant shift in their relationship.

response_text: Linda Keren Godfrey is a South African engineer and Principal Scientist at the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in South Africa. She is a specialist in the circular economy. She was elected a Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Early life and education == Godfrey studied chemistry at Rhodes University. She earned a Master's in hydrogeology at the University of the Free State. Godfrey earned her doctorate in engineering at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, where she studied waste data. == Research and career == Godfrey manages Circular Innovation South Africa, a programme that looks to move the country to a more circular and sustainable economy. She has argued that half of climate impacts and most biodiversity loss comes from the extraction and processing of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Godfrey was elected Fellow of the Royal Academy of Engineering in 2025. == Publications == Winnie W Y Lau; Yonathan Shiran; Richard

response_text: Effingham Brown Sutton (April 17, 1817 – May 27, 1891) was an American shipping merchant and real-estate developer best known as an early builder in the area of Manhattan that later became known as Sutton Place. During the California Gold Rush, Sutton prospered not by mining but by operating ships serving the booming New York–San Francisco trade. == Career == Sutton was a shipping merchant who profited during the 1849 California Gold Rush, when American clipper ships rapidly expanded service to San Francisco. In 1875, Sutton built a row of brownstone houses between East 57th and 58th Streets along a formerly disconnected segment of Avenue A on Manhattan's East River. The area was later renamed Sutton Place (1883) and, in the 20th century, became a fashionable enclave following redevelopment by architects such as Mott B. Schmidt. == Properties == Beyond Manhattan, Sutton maintained a Long Island estate known as Effingham Park at West Islip. Photographs and genealogical materials relating to the estate are preserved in the Richard C. Sutton papers at the New York Public Library. == Death and legacy == Sutton died in 1891. In 1997, New York City renamed a series of vest-pocket parks along the East River between 53rd and 59th Streets as "Sutton Place Park" in his honor, reflecting his role in the area's 19th-century development. == References == == Further reading == Christopher Collora, Long Island Historic Houses of the South Shore — includes discussion of Effingham Park in West Islip.

response_text: Mercury(II) perchlorate is an inorganic chemical compound with the formula Hg(ClO4)2·nH2O, where n can range from 0 to 6. The anhydrous and hydrates are all toxic, water-soluble, and hygroscopic white solids. == Preparation and reactions == Hydrates of mercury(II) perchlorate are most commonly prepared by the reaction of mercury(II) oxide and concentrated perchloric acid: HgO + 2 HClO4 → Hg(ClO4)2 + H2O Evaporation of the resulting solution results in the formation of the hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, which can be converted to lower hydrates, such as the dihydrate, by heating to 30 °C in a vacuum. Further heating does not produce the anhydrous form, but instead forms a basic mercury perchlorate. The anhydrous form is produced by dehydrating the dihydrate with anhydrous perchloric acid or dichlorine hexoxide. Solutions of mercury(II) perchlorate in water reacts with aqueous ammonia to produce tetraamminemercury(II) perchlorate, [Hg(NH3)4](ClO4)2. Heating of the tetraammine complex results in the diammine complex. Mercury(II) perchlorate also reacts with elemental mercury to form mercury(I) perchlorate: Hg(ClO4)2 + Hg → Hg2(ClO4)2 == Structure == The solid hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, has a trigonal crystal structure and consists of octahederal [Hg(H2O)6]2+ centers and ClO4– ions. The anhydrous form was probed by IR spectroscopy and was found to consist of monodendate perchlorate ions. == Applications == Mercury(II) perchlorate finds limited applications in organic synthesis, such as in the hydrolysis of vinyl halides and the allylation of isatins and isatin ketoimines. == References ==

It is the type species for the genus Camptoceras. This species has no taxonomic synonyms. One source classifies the Japanese species Camptoceras hirasei as a subspecies of C. terebra (Camptoceras terebra hirasei). One syntype (specimen used in Benson's original description) is in the collections of the Natural History Museum of London. == Description == The shell of Camptoceras terebra is long and skinny, with a height of about 6 to 7 mm (0.24 to 0.28 in) and a diameter of about 3 mm (0.12 in). At maximum, the shell may reach about 9 mm (0.35 in) in height. The shell opening, called the aperture, is about 4 mm (0.16 in) in the largest dimension. The revolutions of the shell, called whorls, curl to the left in a condition known as sinistry. The whorls are few in number and are not fused. A sculpture (3-dimensional protrusions of the shell) may be present in the form of varices. These varices are projections of the edge of the aperture at different points in the animal's life, and look similar to those found in the unrelated genus Epitonium. The sculpture does not include spiral striae. This species possesses proportionally large eyes relative to its body,

She was also the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. Schmidt-Nielsen collaborated with her husband in natural science research and publications, including into the rennet of calves and the vitamin content of herrings. == Death == Schmidt-Nielsen died in 1959 in Stockholm. It inhabits rocky seafloors in the tropical western Pacific Ocean at depths exceeding 400 meters, where it forms solitary colonies up to 1.2 meters tall. == Description == Iridogorgia chewbacca features a monopodial, spiral axis typical of its genus, with a brilliant iridescence that gives it a shimmering appearance under light. The colony grows upright and solitary, reaching heights of ~1.2 meters (4 feet) in specimens from near Molokaʻi, Hawaii, while those near the Mariana Trench measure around 50 cm (20 inches). Its branches are long and flexible, stretching up to 38 cm (15 inches), hanging downward in a "shaggy" manner that resembles hair, distinguishing it from stiffer-branched relatives. The polyps, numbering thousands per colony, extend tentacles for filter-feeding and give the branches a fuzzy texture when active. Unlike many corals that form dense reefs, I. chewbacca occurs scattered and alone on hard substrates, with its shiny, iridescent surface reflecting light in patterns akin to "fireworks exploding from the seafloor". Genetic markers, including mtMutS-cox1 and 28S rDNA, confirm its distinction from congeners, though mtMutS showed limited utility for delimitation within the genus. Spiral growth direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise) does not serve as a reliable taxonomic trait. == Taxonomy == Iridogorgia chewbacca belongs to the genus Iridogorgia, in the family Chrysogorgiidae, order Malacalcyonacea, class Octocorallia, phylum Cnidaria. == George and Willie Muse ==

George and Willie Muse were African-American albino brothers born into slavery. George was born on June 15, 1865, and Willie was born on May 19, 1868. Both brothers were born with albinism. The brothers were kidnapped from their home in Roanoke, Virginia by a man named James Herman "Candy" Shelton, who forced them to perform in circuses and traveling shows for approximately 18 years without pay.

== Circus careers ==

The brothers were first displayed as circus curiosities in 1882, when Shelton forced them to perform under the stage names "Eko" and "Iko" or as the "Ambassadors from Mars". They performed in various circuses and sideshows, including the Ringling Brothers Circus, where they were often described as exotic and otherworldly due to their albinism. Their performances included playing musical instruments and engaging in various circus acts, often being billed as extraterrestrial or from distant lands.

== Eugenics movement ==

The brothers were also victims of the eugenics movement. They were featured in materials promoting eugenics, particularly in the American eugenics movement where a picture of them was displayed within the book titled "You and Heredity". The author of the book Amram Scheinfeld would go on to point out the brothers albinism, nystagmus and teeth defects.

== Later life ==

In 1927, the Ringling Brothers Circus passed through Roanoke. Their mother, Harriet Muse, interrupted a performance and confronted circus proprietors and city cops. During this interruption she was reunited with her sons, who had been missing and working without pay for 18 years. Three days later Harriet would begin legal proceedings to try and recover her sons unpaid wages and to hold the Ringling Brothers and her sons abductor James Herman "Candy" Shelton accountable. Harriet's lawyer argued that the brothers had been turned into slaves, which lead to a settlement where the circus agree to pay back the brothers wages. The brothers were also offered a deal to return to the circus where a portion of their salary would be paid to their parents and their younger brother Tom (who also exhibited albinism) would be given employment. George died in 1971 at the age of 80 years old, while Willie died in 2001 aged 108.

== Family ==

The Muse brothers' parents were Cabell Muse and Harriet Muse, who were both descendants of former slaves. After the kidnapping of the brothers, their mother would go on to have three more children named Tom, Annie Belle and Harrison. All five of the mother's children were born with albinism. response_text: Laura Toenjes is the superintendent of the Kyrene School District serving the Ahwatukee, south Tempe, and west Chandler communities in the state of Arizona. After Vesely announced retirement in October 2020, the school board immediately promoted Toenjes to the superintendent role. Her career has also included positions at Sunnyside Unified School District and Arizona Department of Education. == Notable decisions == In February 2025, the Kyrene Governing Board created the Long Range Planning Committee. Toenjes was involved, and vetted 58 members of the committee. As of October 1, 2025, the planning committee is recommending closing 9 out of 25 schools, with final school board decision scheduled for December 2025. In April 2025, Toenjes re-affirmed that the school district's "policies around equity, inclusion and social-emotional wellness—are fully compliant with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964." Arizona Superintendent of Public Instruction Tom Horne threatened to withhold $1.5 million of federal funding per guidance from the United States Department of Education. The guidance was subsequently revoked, and district was properly funded. == References ==

response_text:
I Don't Know How is the third studio album by Scottish singer-songwriter Frightened Rabbit. The album was released on 23 September 2016 through the independent record label Xtorr, following the 2013 release of Pedestrian Verse. Most of the album has an indie pop and indie rock sound, and it features vocal harmonies and extensive use of synthesisers. The album features a guest appearance from American musician Bon Iver. The title track "I Don't Know How" is a co-production between McRae and Bon Iver's Justin Vernon.

Thematically, the album focuses on self-reflection, heartbreak, loss and reconciliation. McRae recorded the album over a period of two years across Los Angeles and Edinburgh. The album received positive reviews from music critics and was praised for its emotional depth and production choices. Critics highlighted the balance McRae struck between darker lyrical subject matter and brighter sonic textures.

The album received a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

response_text:
Lecanora species#
**Lecanora species** is a lichenized fungus. It is found in Thailand.

== Description ==
Thallus is pale greenish-yellow, rimose, 0.5–1 mm thick, with scattered black areolae and isolated hydrophobic granules that dissolve in KOH without a distinct colour reaction. The subhymenium is about 10 μm high and olive-brown, the epihymenium about 25 μm and dark brown, the hymenium 75–100 μm and hyaline, and the hypothecium 100–170 μm and blackish-brown, with a K– reaction. Asci measure 65–80 × 10–15 μm. Ascospores number 6–8 (occasionally as few as 4) per ascus, are colourless, ellipsoid, non-septate and halonate, 10–13 (more rarely up to 17) × 6–8 μm with an approximately 1-μm halo. Reported chemistry includes atranorin (major) with several as-yet unidentified lichen substances (minor). == Habitat and distribution == Known from northern Thailand, the species grows on tree bark in evergreen montane forest near the Doi Mon Larn–Mae Kampong area east-south-east of Chiang Mai, where the canopy is dominated by Lithocarpus, Quercus and Castanopsis. == References ==

response_text: Lecania brunneosaxa is a rare, recently described species of lichen that is obligately corticolous. The thallus is pale greenish-grey, thin and rimose, with an indistinct prothallus. The apothecia are sparse, 0.5–1.5 mm in diameter, and have a flat to slightly convex disc that ranges in colour from reddish-brown to blackish-brown, with a lighter coloured thalline margin that is either level with or slightly raised above the disc. June and John is a 2024 science fiction romantic drama film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Cara Delevingne as June and Nicholas Hoult as John.

== Plot ==

The film follows June, a free-spirited young woman who meets John, a reserved introvert, in a chance encounter in Paris. Their relationship develops as they explore the city together, sharing dreams and secrets. As they navigate the complexities of young love, they discover that their connection transcends the ordinary, with ethereal cinematography highlighting their emotional journey.

== Reception ==

The film received mixed reviews from critics upon its release. Many praised Besson's visual direction but criticized the screenplay for its shallow exploration of character development.

Le Figaro's critic wrote: "What undermines 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==

June and John at IMDb

The tract originated in 17th-century Dutch and English land patents and, after a long chain of title, was acquired by merchant Thomas Pearsall in 1797 and devised to his son Thomas C. Pearsall in 1807. By the early 19th century the holding encompassed portions of today's East 50s near the East River and the old Post Road; the site was gradually absorbed by the Manhattan street grid during the 19th century. == History == The acreage that later formed the Pearsall farm originated in colonial grants near Turtle Bay. A 1676 patent from Governor Edmund Andros to John Danielson described roughly thirty acres northeast of "Deutel" (Turtle) Bay, bounded by the commons and lands of Jacobus Fabricius and David De Voor. Through the late 17th and 18th centuries, title passed among owners including John Jennings, Pieter Boeckhout (Bockholst), and the Hardman family; parts of the tract were associated with the Union Flag tavern on the Post Road. In 1784 the farm was conveyed to printer and bookseller Hugh Gaine, and in 1795 to attorney Josiah Ogden Hoffman. On April 27, 1797, Hoffman sold the property to New York merchant Thomas Pearsall. response_text: The Pearsall Farm was a historic property located in the Turtle Bay area of Manhattan in present-day New York City. The farm tract originated in the 17th century as part of the Fabricius patent, a large land grant in the area. The original Pearsall holding comprised approximately 24 acres northeast of "Deutel" (Turtle) Bay, bounded by the commons and lands of Jacobus Fabricius and David De Voor. Through the late 17th and 18th centuries, title passed among owners including John Jennings, Pieter Boeckhout (Bockholst), and the Hardman family; parts of the tract were associated with the Union Flag tavern on the Post Road. In 1784 the farm was conveyed to printer and bookseller Hugh Gaine, and in 1795 to attorney Josiah Ogden Hoffman. On April 27, 1797, Hoffman sold the property to New York merchant Thomas Pearsall. Pearsall's 1805 will gave his "country seat" to his wife for life, with remainder to his son Thomas C. Pearsall; the elder Pearsall died in 1807, and the devise took effect thereafter. In 1809, Thomas C. Pearsall purchased an additional parcel (about four acres) that had been part of the Fabricius patent, consolidating the holding along the river and Post Road. == Location and description == Nineteenth-century descriptions place the farmhouse near the later bed of Avenue A (now roughly First Avenue) between East 58th and 59th Streets, with frontage on the East River and the Post Road. Contemporary advertisements cited orchard and garden improvements, a wharf and landing, and access to rich fisheries in the adjacent cove at Turtle Bay. == Later development == By the 19th century the Pearsall lands—like neighboring estates at Turtle Bay—were surveyed into city lots as Manhattan's grid advanced. Subsequent owners subdivided and conveyed the tract, and the farm landscape disappeared beneath urban residential and commercial development. == Legacy and documentation

The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. 'June & John' is a 2024 science fiction romantic drama film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Léa Seydoux as June and Timothée Chalamet as John. It was released on June 5, 2024.

The film follows June, a woman in her twenties who encounters John, a mysterious man who seems to exist outside of time. Together, they embark on a surreal journey through dreamlike landscapes where time operates differently than in the real world. As their relationship develops, they confront questions about the nature of love, mortality and existence.

Besson's directorial choices include the use of AI-generated imagery mixed with live-action sequences, creating a visually distinctive but often jarring aesthetic. The cinematography alternates between hyper-saturated colors and desaturated scenes, intended to represent emotional states rather than conventional narrative progression.

Critical reception has been largely negative. Critics found the film's technical ambition overshadowed by a thin narrative and underdeveloped characters. Le Figaro wrote, "What ultimately brings down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. Mikako (未紀子, 1835–1894) was a Japanese woman, the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and final Tokugawa shōgun of Japan.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835 as the daughter of Makino Tadakage. In 1853, she married Tokugawa Yoshinobu, a young man who was in line to become shōgun. The couple had several children together, though most were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside == In popular culture == She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi". == References ==

Mikako (美賀子) (1835 – July 9, 1894) was the Gorenju, a formal title for the official wife of a shōgun. Mikako was the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th Tokugawa shōgun.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835 as the daughter of Shimazu Narioki, the daimyo of Satsuma Domain. She was married to Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the future shōgun, in 1853 when she was 18 years old. The marriage was arranged to strengthen relations between the Tokugawa and Shimazu families. The couple had four children together, though all of them died in infancy, a common occurrence in the era where many infants and children were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gumi".

== References ==

response_text: Signe Torborg Schmidt-Nielsen (née Sturtzen-Becker, 1 December 1878 – 1959) was a Swedish-Norwegian physicist and nutritionist. She was the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. == Family == Signe Torborg Sturtzen-Becker was born on 1 December 1878 in Stockholm. Her parents were Vilhelm Teodor Patrik Sturzen-Becker (1841–1910), the son of Swedish poet Oscar Patric Sturzen-Becker, and Astrid Sturzen-Becker (née Paykull, 1848–1908). Sturtzen-Becker married chemist Sigval Schmidt-Nielsen [no, sv] in 1907 in Stockholm. They had four children, including the physiologist Knut Schmidt-Nielsen (1915–2007), who emigrated to America and worked at Duke University. == Career == Schmidt-Nielsen studied for her PhD in physics at Stockholm University and was one of the first women in Sweden to receive a doctoral degree when she graduated in 1907. She was also the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. Schmidt-Nielsen collaborated with her husband in natural science research and publications, including into the rennet of calves and the vitamin content of herrings. == Death == Schmidt-Nielsen died in 1959 in Stockholm. She was buried at Domkirkegården, Trondheim, Norway. == References ==

I Don't Know How is the debut studio album by Scottish singer-songwriter Fiona McRae. The album was released on 22 September 2023 on Domino Recording Company. The album was supported by lead single "Seventeen" on 7 June 2023, followed by "Company" on 9 August 2023, and "Bud" on 6 September 2023.

I Don't Know How received generally positive reviews from music critics. On Metacritic, the album holds a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

response_text: Héctor Rodríguez Álvarez (1900–1970) was a Chilean lawyer and politician. == Early life == He was born on 11 October 1900. He studied law at the University of Chile, where he specialized in civil procedure, earning his law degree in 1924. His thesis dealt with reform to the Código de Procesamiento Civil. He married Marta Johannsen Bonchert; they had two children, Humberto and Marta. == Professional career == He worked as secretary-lawyer of the Municipality of Coquimbo (1921–1922), served as relator of the Court of Appeals of La Serena, was secretary to the Civil Code reform commission, and legal secretary of the Association of Electric and Mining Companies. He later practiced law with Gabriel González Videla and Pedro Enrique Alfonso. In business, he presided over the Compañía Olivarera Nacional, the Compañía de Conservas e Industrias Pesqueras S.A., and the Sociedad Pesquera of Iquique. From 1947 he taught procedural law at the University of Chile. == Political career == A member of the Radical Party, Álvarez was elected Deputy for the 4th Departmental Group (La Serena, Elqui, Coquimbo) for the 1933–1937 term. He resigned his seat upon being appointed Minister of Justice by President Arturo Alessandri Palma (12 September–22 October 1936). He was reelected Deputy for 1937–1941 (now covering La Serena, Elqui, Coquimbo, Ovalle, Illapel and Combarbalá), serving on the Committees of Social Legislation and Justice; Government; Constitution, Legislation and Justice; Finance; and the Joint Committee on the Organic Law of Courts. He again left the Chamber when appointed Minister of the Interior by President Pedro Aguirre Cerda (8 February–30 July 1940); his seat was filled by Rodolfo Masson Villarroel after a by-election. Álvarez was then elected Senator for Atacama and Coquimbo in 1941 and reelected in 1949 and 1957, serving until 1965. response_text: August Eduard Johnson (February 16, 1840 – September 7, 1903) was a German classicist, teacher, journalist and local historian. He used the pseudonyms E. Joannides and Georg Capellanus. Although the name "Johnson" appears to be an English name, it is not. The original form of the family name was apparently "Joh(a)nsson". == Life == After attending primary school and the Gymnasium (college preparatory school) in his home town of Freiberg, Germany, Johnson studied philosophy and philology at the university in Leipzig, with the intention of becoming a teacher at an advanced secondary school. In 1864, after passing the state exam and earning a Doctor of Philosopy degree, he began his probationary year of teaching at the Plauen Gymnasium. He taught Latin, Greek, German and History. In 1865 he finished his probationary year and earned a fixed employment position at the school. While employed as a teacher, he published philosophical works on the problem of Sensualism and made extensive investigations into the history of the Vogtland in Saxony, Germany. After his transfer to the Chemnitz Gymnasium in 1881, he used his free time for excursions to the Vogtland. As a historian he published several reports on the history of notable individuals and castles in the Vogtland. Between 1896 and 1903 he published over 162 articles under the title Vogtländische Altertümer (Vogtland Antiquities). Johnson worried about the waning influence of Ancient Greek and Latin. He pseudonymously published two books cataloguing colloquial phrases and vocabulary in order to promote the active use of Greek and Latin in everyday

response_text: Geolycosa subvittata is a species of spider in the family Lycosidae. It is endemic to South Africa and is commonly known as the Cape Geolycosa wolf spider. == Distribution == Geolycosa subvittata is found in the Eastern Cape and Western Cape provinces of South Africa. Notable locations include Grahamstown (now Makhanda), Port Elizabeth, Table Mountain National Park, Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden, and several other sites in the Cape region. == Habitat and ecology == This species is a ground dweller known to live in burrows. It has been sampled from the Fynbos and Thicket biomes at altitudes ranging from 5 to 552 m. == Description == Known from both sexes, Geolycosa subvittata is smaller than the related G. hectoria but has a similar dorsal color pattern. It has two yellow stripes on the abdomen. Ventrally, it bears a median longitudinal black stripe. The tibiae are not distinctly banded. Males measure 11 mm in total length, while females measure 14 mm. == Conservation == The species has a large range and is protected in Table Mountain National Park and Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden. However, most specimens were sampled around 1900, and the species is threatened by loss of habitat. == Taxonomy == The species was originally described by Pocock in 1900 as Lycosa subvittata from Port Elizabeth. It was later revised by Roewer in 1959. == References ==

response_text: Lutz van Dijk is a German-Namibian author, educationalist, and human rights activist. Van Dijk was born in Berlin. In his childhood, he lived in Oldenburg. In his writing, Van Dijk deals with topics related to Nazism and homosexuality and, since 2018, he has published children's books. Van Dijk also wrote Kampala-Hamburg, a book about a gay refugee from Uganda who escapes persecution in his native country and flees to Hamburg with the help of German LGBTQ+ activists. Van Dijk wrote most of his books in German, with many of them translated into Afrikaans, Xhosa, and English. In 2024, he wrote an autobiography recounting his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall, and his decision to move to New York City as soon as he turned 18. In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002. == Awards and nominations == Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. In 1997, Van Dijk was awarded with the Youth Literature Award of Namibia and, in 2001, he received the Gustav Heinemann Peace Prize. == References ==

== Linda Godfrey ==
Linda Godfrey is a South African waste management scientist and engineer. She is a researcher at the University of Cape Town, in the Waste Research, Development and Innovation (RDI) Roadmap division. Godfrey specializes in integrating waste management into the circular economy as a way of sustainably utilizing resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. response_text: Eaton Rapids Public Schools is a public school district in the Lansing, Michigan area. In Eaton County, it serves Eaton Rapids and parts of the townships of Brookfield, Eaton, Eaton Rapids, Hamlin, and Windsor. In Ingham County, it serves parts of the townships of Aurelius, Delhi, and Onondaga. == History == The first commencement at Eaton Rapids High School was in 1875. A brick school was built in 1886 on the north side of King Street near the end of West Street. It was ultimately known as the West Building. An elementary school was built to the east of it, and the high school was built to the north of the elementary on the west side of Hall Street in 1923. The West Building was condemned by the state fire marshal in 1939, but the high school continued to hold classes in it due to overcrowding. It was torn down when the new high school opened. As of 1962, high school classes were held in three other buildings, including the 1923 high school, which was converted to a junior high when the current high school opened. Northwestern Elementary was built in 1959 and closed in 2011. Union Street Elementary was built in 1962. The architect was Guido A. Binda. Currently it is known as Union Street Center and houses the Early Learning Center and other programs for the community. The current high school opened in fall 1963. Warren Holmes Co. was the architect. The opening of the high school was marred by vandalism. A few days

response_text:
June & John is a 2015 science fiction romantic drama film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Cara Delevingne as June and Nat Wolff as John, two young lovers who navigate a futuristic world through virtual reality and artificial intelligence.

== Plot ==
June and John are two teenagers living in a near-future world dominated by technology. They meet in a virtual reality space and fall in love, but their romance is complicated by the interventions of an advanced AI system designed to regulate human emotions and relationships. As their bond deepens, they must choose between their authentic feelings and the algorithmic predictions made about their compatibility.

== Reception ==
The film received mixed to negative reviews from critics. Many praised its visual style and ambitious use of technology, but criticized its shallow treatment of its central themes. Critics noted that while the film was technically impressive, it lacked emotional depth and meaningful character development.

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde was particularly critical, noting: "What prevents one from fully embracing 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

The film follows June and John, two young people who meet in a futuristic setting and fall in love while navigating a world transformed by advanced artificial intelligence and virtual reality technology.

The film received mixed reviews from critics upon its release. Critics praised the visual effects and cinematography but criticized the screenplay and character development.

The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5,

June and John is a 2024 science fiction romantic film written and directed by Luc Besson. It stars Léa Seydoux and Jesse Plemons as the titular characters, and features an experimental blend of live-action and AI-generated imagery.

Plot

June, a young woman struggling with loneliness in a crowded city, discovers an AI companion named John. Initially designed to understand her needs, John gradually becomes more than a program—he becomes her confidant and romantic interest. As June and John's relationship deepens, the line between artificial and real blurs, forcing June to question the nature of love and human connection. When a glitch threatens to erase John's memory, June must decide whether their love is worth saving, even if it exists in the digital realm.

Reception

Critics were mixed on the film. While some praised Besson's ambitious attempt at blending genres and technologies, most felt the execution fell short. Vincent Canby of The New York Times wrote, "What ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it."
