response_text:
Sutton Place is a historic gated community in the Beaux-Arts style on the East Side of Midtown Manhattan in New York City. It is located between First Avenue and the East River, and between East 57th and East 59th Streets. The neighborhood was developed in the 1870s by Effingham B. Sutton, a Philadelphia merchant, as a fashionable residential enclave. It was designed by George F. Pelham in the Beaux-Arts style, which was popular for high-end residential architecture of the period.

The community features elegant townhouses and mansion apartments, which have attracted numerous wealthy residents and celebrities throughout its history. Notable residents have included the Rockefeller family, and the neighborhood has maintained its exclusive character over the decades. The tree-lined streets and private gardens create an elegant urban oasis in the heart of Manhattan.

The architecture is characterized by ornate facades, wrought iron details, and refined proportions typical of the Beaux-Arts movement. Many of the original buildings have been carefully preserved, maintaining the neighborhood's historic integrity and architectural significance. The gated nature of the community has helped preserve its distinctive character and charm.

In the early 20th century, Sutton Place continued to develop as an exclusive residential neighborhood. The opening of the Queensboro Bridge in 1909 improved access to the area. Over time, the neighborhood attracted artists, intellectuals, and society figures who appreciated its refined atmosphere and proximity to cultural institutions.

The River Book House was an early commercial establishment in the neighborhood. On May 7, 1932, the River Book House opened at 444 East 58th Street, by E. R. Armstrong and J. M. Wolcott. Announced in Publishers Weekly as a new neighborhood bookshop, it was styled to serve the growing Sutton Place community and took its name from the nearby East River.

== See also ==
Sutton Place, Manhattan
George F. Pelham
Beaux-Arts architecture in New York City
Architecture of New York City

== Further reading ==

Gray, Christopher. New York Streetscapes: Tales of Manhattan's Significant Buildings and Landmarks. New York: Harry N. Abrams, 2003. ISBN 978-0810944418.
Stern, Robert A. M.; Gilmartin, Gregory; Mellins, Thomas. New York 1900: Metropolitan Architecture and Urbanism 1890–1915. New York: Rizzoli, 1983. ISBN 978-0847804534.
White, Norval; Willensky, Elliot; Leadon, Fran. AIA Guide to New York City. 5th ed., New York: Oxford University Press, 2010. ISBN 978-0195383867.

response_text: GJ 1289 b is a sub-Neptune exoplanet orbiting the red dwarf star GJ 1289, located approximately 8.86 parsecs (≈29 light-years) from the Sun. It was discovered using radial-velocity measurements with the near-infrared spectropolarimeter SPIRou at the Canada–France–Hawaii Telescope over multiple years, revealing a minimum mass of 6.27 ± 1.25 Earth masses and a nearly circular orbit with a period of 111.74 days. The host star, an M4.5V fully convective red dwarf with a mass of 0.21 solar masses, exhibits a strong large-scale dipolar magnetic field of 200–240 G and a rotation period of ~73.7 days, which is distinct from the planet's orbital period. The planet's orbital distance places it beyond the conventional habitable zone of its cool, low-luminosity host, though it may still have a temperate atmosphere, making it a target for further study. Its discovery is notable for demonstrating the detection of planets around fully convective M dwarfs, whose magnetic activity differs significantly from that of partly convective stars, and for showing that low-amplitude radial-velocity signals can be reliably extracted even in the presence of strong stellar magnetic fields. == References ==

response_text: Norman Kerr was a New Zealand cardiac and cardiothoracic surgeon. == Early life and education == Kerr was born in New Zealand and trained in medicine at the University of Otago. == Medical career == Kerr worked at Green Lane Hospital in Auckland, initially in a paediatric position at Green Lane in 1969. He worked in the cardio-thoracic surgical team with Brian Barratt-Boyes and was one of the surgeons who performed the first heart-lung bypass operation at Green Lane in 1958. Staff from Green Lane hosted and trained doctors from overseas and visited foreign hospitals In 1981 Kerr visited hospitals in New Delhi and Madras (now Chennai) doing cardiopulmonary bypass operations and delivering training in cardiac surgery. A special supplement of the New Zealand Medical Journal, published in 2001, honoured the work of Kerr and five other cardiology and cardiothoracic consultants: Trevor Agnew, Pat Clarkson, John Mercer, John Neutze, and Toby Whitlock. == Work in Palestine == In 2001 Kerr joined the Palestine Children's Relief Fund volunteering his services as a paediatric cardiac surgeon. Between 2001 and 2018 he made over 40 trips to the West Bank and Gaza working in Makassed Hospital in East Jerusalem, Palestine Medical Complex in Ramallah and Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza. As well as doing surgery he trained other surgeons and developed the paediatric surgery programme at Makassed. In 2007 film maker Paula Whetu Jones commenced filming Kerr and his wife Hazel on their trips to Palestine. Hazel worked with children in refugee camps and at a school for deaf children teaching art and drama. The film The Doctor's Wife was released in 2025. == Honours and awards == Kerr was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit, for services to cardiothoracic surgery, in the 1997 New Year Honours. == Selected works ==

As well as doing surgery he trained other surgeons and developed the paediatric surgery programme at Makassed. In 2007 film maker Paula Whetu Jones commenced filming Kerr and his wife Hazel on their trips to Palestine. Hazel worked with children in refugee camps and at a school for deaf children teaching art and drama. == June and John ==

'June & John' is a 2024 science fiction romance film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Cara Delevingne as June and Nicholas Hoult as John, two young people who fall in love in a near-future dystopia. The film was shot in 8K resolution and uses artificial intelligence to generate some of its visual effects.

The film follows June and John as they navigate their relationship in a world where artificial intelligence has become the dominant force. They meet in a virtual reality space and begin to develop feelings for each other. As their relationship deepens, they must decide whether to remain in the virtual world or venture into the real world together.

'June & John' was met with mixed reviews from critics. Some praised the film's visual innovation and the chemistry between Delevingne and Hoult, while others criticized the film's plot and dialogue. The film was a commercial success, grossing over $200 million worldwide.

Critic reviews

Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote in a review, "What sinks 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

The **Humboldthain** is a public park in Berlin-Wedding, laid out on the grounds of a former Zoological Garden (Zoologischer Garten Wedding). Today it features among other things two towers that were erected during World War II as part of Berlin's air defense, and the Humboldthain Club.

== History ==
=== Early years ===
The site originally hosted a zoological garden that operated from 1954 until the early 1960s. The zoological garden had a chapel located in its southern section. From 1940 onward, two massive concrete flak towers (anti-aircraft gun towers) were constructed in the park as part of Berlin's air-defense network. Building was around the clock with up to 3,200 workers, including foreign laborers and POWs. After 1945, the command tower was demolished and buried; the northern tower was only partially demolished (nearby rail lines limited blasting). The site was reshaped with large volumes of rubble to form today's Humboldthöhe. Contemporary reporting also recounts the postwar blasting attempts and their limits. From the late 1940s to early 1950s the grounds were reconstructed as a public park. A formal rose garden (Rosengarten) was laid out on the former church site and remains a key feature of the southern section.

=== Recent decades ===
Informal urban explorers dug their way in and noted a fatal fall inside the Humboldthain bunker in 1982, underscoring why access today is controlled and guided. In the early 2000s, blocked passages were cleared and routes were secured inside the Humboldthain tower. Guided visits have since run seasonally, typically April–October; three of the tower's seven floors are shown, after volunteers removed over 1,400 m³ of debris across 8,000+ hours of work, with helmets required and a 90-minute route designed to avoid disturbing hibernating bats.

== Features ==
Bat hibernation site: The interior hosts several bat species in winter; it is one of Berlin's larger winter shelters for bats. Bunker tours: Regular guided visits to multiple levels of the flak structure. Humboldthain Club: In May 2013, the Club opened inside the station building at Hochstraße 46, next to the park. Humboldthain is a public park in Wedding, Berlin. The park covers 86.5 hectares (214 acres) in the northern part of the district. It was established in 1869 on the grounds of the former Humboldt Estate. The park features two large artificial hills (the Humboldthöhe and the Montegehalt), which were built from rubble following World War II.

== History ==
=== 19th century origins ===
The park was established in 1869 by the Berlin city government. It was named after the Humboldt family, who were prominent Prussian naturalists and explorers. The original landscape design was based on the English landscape garden tradition.

=== World War II ===
Two large anti-aircraft gun tower bunkers (Flakturm towers) were constructed in the park as part of Berlin's air-defense network. Building was around the clock with up to 3,200 workers, including foreign laborers and POWs. After 1945, the command tower was demolished and buried; the northern tower was only partially demolished (nearby rail lines limited blasting). The site was reshaped with large volumes of rubble to form today's Humboldthöhe. Contemporary reporting also recounts the postwar blasting attempts and their limits. From the late 1940s to early 1950s the grounds were reconstructed as a public park. A formal rose garden (Rosengarten) was laid out on the former church site and remains a key feature of the southern section.

=== Recent decades ===
Informal urban explorers dug their way in and noted a fatal fall inside the Humboldthain bunker in 1982, underscoring why access today is controlled and guided. In the early 2000s, blocked passages were cleared and routes were secured inside the Humboldthain tower. Guided visits have since run seasonally, typically April–October; three of the tower's seven floors are shown, after volunteers removed over 1,400 m³ of debris across 8,000+ hours of work, with helmets required and a 90-minute route designed to avoid disturbing hibernating bats.

== Features ==
Bat hibernation site: The interior hosts several bat species in winter; it is one of Berlin's larger winter shelters for bats. Bunker tours: Regular guided visits to multiple levels of the flak structure. Humboldthain Club: In May 2013, the Club opened inside the station building at Hochstraße 46, next to the park. Operator Constantin Boese launched

response_text: Slapshot (band) Slapshot is a hardcore punk band from Boston, Massachusetts, formed in 1982. The band is known for their energetic live shows and have been described as one of the most important bands in the Boston hardcore scene. == Olde Tyme Hardcore == Olde Tyme Hardcore is the third studio album by Boston hardcore punk band Slapshot, released in 1996 on Taang! Records. The album showcases the band's signature raw and aggressive sound and features a cover of the SSD track Get It Away. The album starts with a clip from the '70s hockey movie that gave Slapshot their band name. The album title is a reference to multiple things: it nods to hockey, Boston's Revolutionary War–themed tourist culture, and to the idea that their hardcore sound was already considered old-fashioned at the time. At the time of the albums release various reports stated lead singer disbanded the group the day after the albums release citing "the idiocy of a scene that is increasingly predominated by college frat boys who will mosh to anything that even closely resembles punk." However the group still went on tours and eventually released a compilation album in 2001. == Reception == German music review Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them." == Track listing == == Personnel == Slapshot Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals Mike Bowser – guitar Chris Lauria – bass Mark Mckay – drums

response_text: 29 Washington Square West is a residential building in the Greenwich Village neighborhood of Manhattan in New York City. The building was constructed in 1909 and designed by architect Robert D. Kohn. It is a 13-story neo-Renaissance apartment house. In 2019, the building's board achieved its goal of becoming debt-free. == Tenants and demographics == === 1910 census === In 1910, the U.S. census recorded primarily immigrant families from Austria, Bohemia, Russia, England, Romania, Germany, Holland, Switzerland, and Armenia. Heads of household included bakers, machinists, hatmakers, merchants, decorators, hotel workers, carpenters, plumbers, policemen, bartenders, dressmakers, and janitors. A total of 82 people lived in the building, averaging 3.15 persons per apartment. === 1920 census === The 1920 census recorded a higher proportion of U.S.-born residents, alongside immigrants from Bavaria, Germany, Russia, Puerto Rico, Austria, Hungary, Canada, England, Ireland, Holland, Poland, and Slovakia. Occupations included plumbers, cigar makers, librarians, taxi drivers, bakers, clerks, barbers, teachers, druggists, and jewelers. 94 people lived in the building, averaging 3.62 per apartment. === 1930 census === The 1930 census listed tenants from Sweden, Russia, Norway, Holland, Canada, Germany, England, Italy, the Philippines, and Northern Ireland. Professions included building superintendent, glass glazer, fur cutter, grocery owner, teacher, hotel chef, film director, musician (Mario Braggiotti), and dance instructor (Gloria Braggiotti Etting). 66 people lived in the building, averaging 2.53 per apartment. === 1940 census === By 1940, the census reflected fewer immigrants, with residents from France, England, Sweden, Wales, Germany, Austria, and Hungary. Occupations included draftsman, advertising publisher, radio writer, teacher, fashion artist, songwriter (Jerry Seelen), and real estate manager. 57 people lived in the building, averaging 2.19 per apartment. === 1950 census === The first post–World War II census recorded residents from Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Austria, France, Germany, and Canada. The album received a rating of 4.5 from Spill, whose reviewer Victoria Love-Rainbow called it "an explosive wave of alternative bliss that will sweep listeners off their feet." Jack McGill of Distorted Sound gave it a rating of six, observing that it "sounds like an album by someone that used to write invigorating rock ballads, but has just lost some of the spark, it's not necessarily bad, but this third record feels like a shade of Press Club." == Track listing == == References ==

response_text: Charles Carshon (c. 1920 – October 28, 2011) was an American actor, theatre director, and acting teacher. A veteran of Broadway and Off-Broadway, he taught at several New York City conservatories and for 35 years headed the Studio Theatre at Sarah Lawrence College. The New York Times obituary called him an "actor, director, teacher, [and] Off-Broadway pioneer." == Career == Carshon's early stage credits included two Broadway productions: The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov–Dec 1950) and Billy Budd (Feb–May 1951). By the mid-1950s he was active Off-Broadway, heading his own company, the Tapestry Theatre. He later performed in the 1975 Off-Broadway production Beethoven/Karl and collaborated frequently with his wife, Gloria Barret Carshon. Carshon was also closely associated with Sarah Lawrence College for decades. As head of the college's Studio Theatre for 35 years, he directed student and resident company productions and mentored generations of actors. In the late 1970s, the Carshons' resident company Green Gate Theatre presented Harold Pinter's Old Times as part of the college's "Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence" series, under Charles and Gloria's direction. == Teaching == Beyond Sarah Lawrence, Carshon taught at New York City's High School of Performing Arts, the Stella Adler Studio, the Neighborhood Playhouse, and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His obituary notes that "many famous actors passed through his classes." == Stage credits (selected) == Broadway The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov 26–Dec 22, 1950) — The Queen's Slave (cast). Billy Budd (Feb 10–May 12, 1951) — company member (replacement). Off-Broadway Beethoven/Karl (1975) — performer. == Personal life ==

response_text:
# Matías Torres Reyes

Matías Torres Reyes (1893–1972) was a Chilean politician and doctor. == Medical career == Torres studied Medicine at the University of Chile, receiving his degree in 1918. He specialized in Public Health and Hospital Management, obtaining a diploma from the International Institute of Public Health in Washington, D.C. (1928). He was Chief of the Public Health Service of Antofagasta (1920–1928), where he organized the first sanitary services for mining workers. He then became Chief Doctor of the Railway Sanitary Service (1928–1933) and Director of Sanitation of the Ministry of Health (1933–1934). In 1934 he was appointed Chief Doctor of the National Health Service and moved to Santiago, where he became Director of San Luis Hospital (1934–1941). Torres also taught at the Schools of Social Service and Nursing of the University of Chile. He represented Chile in several international medical and health conferences, including the Sanitary Technique Congress of Milan (1930), the International Hospital Congress in Vienna (1931), and the International Labour Conference in Geneva (1947, 1952). Beyond medicine, he was involved in business as adviser to Radio Minería, president of the Sociedad Abastecedora de la Minería, and founder of the Compañía Minera "Merceditas." == Political career == Torres joined the Radical Party, serving as vice president of the first Congress of the Radical Youth. He was elected Deputy for Chañaral, Copiapó, Freirina and Huasco (1926–1930), joining the Permanent Commission of Public Assistance and Hygiene. Reelected in the controversial "Thermal Congress" of 1930, his mandate was interrupted in 1932 after the Socialist Revolution. He returned to the Chamber of Deputies in 1933, serving until 1941, integrating the Permanent Commissions of Labour and Social Welfare. In 1941 he was elected Senator for Atacama and Coquimbo, serving uninterruptedly until 1965. He participated in the Commissions of Mining and Industrial Development, Foreign Relations and Trade, Government, Hygiene and Public Health. He was also counsellor of the Caja de Crédito Minero (1949–1953). Between 31 May 1961 and 10 October 1962 he was Vice President of the Senate. == Death == He died in Santiago on 16 July 1972, aged 78. == Bibliography == Fernando Castillo Infante, Diccionario Histórico y Biográfico de Chile. Santiago: Editorial Zig-Zag, 1996. Matías

response_text: Humboldthain is a 27.8-hectare public park in Berlin-Wedding in the Wedding district. It is home to a World War II air defense tower (flak tower), part of the three towers built in Berlin, featuring bat hibernation and guided visits to multiple levels. == Location == The park is bounded by Hochstraße to the west, Böttgerstraße to the east, Wiesenstraße to the north, and Seestraße to the south. The Berlin U-Bahn U6 line runs below the park. == History == === Pre-war === The site was originally Humboldt Park, renamed "Humboldthain" in 1908. Until 1939 it contained a Protestant church (Johanneskirche) as its centerpiece. == World War II era == In 1940-1941, two monumental above-ground flak towers (roughly 40 meters tall, resembling fortress towers) were constructed in the park as part of Berlin's air-defense network. Building was around the clock with up to 3,200 workers, including foreign laborers and POWs. After 1945, the command tower was demolished and buried; the northern tower was only partially demolished (nearby rail lines limited blasting). The site was reshaped with large volumes of rubble to form today's Humboldthöhe. Contemporary reporting also recounts the postwar blasting attempts and their limits. From the late 1940s to early 1950s the grounds were reconstructed as a public park. A formal rose garden (Rosengarten) was laid out on the former church site and remains a key feature of the southern section. === Recent decades === Informal urban explorers dug their way in and noted a fatal fall inside the Humboldthain bunker in 1982, underscoring why access today is controlled and guided. In the early 2000s, blocked passages were cleared and routes were secured inside the Humboldthain tower. Guided visits have since run seasonally, typically April–October; three of the tower's seven floors are shown, after volunteers removed over 1,400 m³ of debris across 8,000+ hours of work, with helmets required and a 90-minute route designed to avoid disturbing hibernating bats. == Features == Bat hibernation site: The interior hosts several bat species in winter; it is one of Berlin's larger winter shelters for bats. Bunker tours: Regular guided visits to multiple levels of the flak structure. Humboldthain Club: In May 2013, the Club opened inside the station building at Hochstraße 46, next to the park. Operator Constantin Boese launched

In 1920, after the incorporation of Moabit into the city of Berlin, the park was expanded. == World War II == Two massive concrete flak towers (anti-aircraft artillery towers) were constructed in the park as part of Berlin's air-defense network. Building was around the clock with up to 3,200 workers, including foreign laborers and POWs. After 1945, the command tower was demolished and buried; the northern tower was only partially demolished (nearby rail lines limited blasting). The site was reshaped with large volumes of rubble to form today's Humboldthöhe. Contemporary reporting also recounts the postwar blasting attempts and their limits. From the late 1940s to early 1950s the grounds were reconstructed as a public park. A formal rose garden (Rosengarten) was laid out on the former church site and remains a key feature of the southern section. === Recent decades === Informal urban explorers dug their way in and noted a fatal fall inside the Humboldthain bunker in 1982, underscoring why access today is controlled and guided. In the early 2000s, blocked passages were cleared and routes were secured inside the Humboldthain tower. Guided visits have since run seasonally, typically April–October; three of the tower's seven floors are shown, after volunteers removed over 1,400 m³ of debris across 8,000+ hours of work, with helmets required and a 90-minute route designed to avoid disturbing hibernating bats. == Features == Bat hibernation site: The interior hosts several bat species in winter; it is one of Berlin's larger winter shelters for bats. Bunker tours: Regular guided visits to multiple levels of the flak structure. Humboldthain Club: In May 2013, the Club opened inside the station building at Hochstraße 46, next to the park. Tokugawa Mikako (1835–1894) was a Japanese noblewoman. She was the second wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the fifteenth and final shogun of the Tokugawa shogunate.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835, the daughter of Shimazu Narioki. She grew up in the Satsuma Domain. At the age of 15, she married Tokugawa Yoshinobu, who was then the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iesada. She gave birth to Tokugawa Ieyoshi soon after, however her son and her mother-in-law died young, along with her first daughter. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem;
On the road where we parted ways
The lingering traces of our love
Like white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gumi".

== References ==

response_text: Geolycosa subvittata is a species of spider in the family Lycosidae. It is endemic to South Africa and is commonly known as the Cape Geolycosa wolf spider. == Distribution == Geolycosa subvittata is found in the Eastern Cape and Western Cape provinces of South Africa. Notable locations include Grahamstown (now Makhanda), Port Elizabeth, Table Mountain National Park, Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden, and several other sites in the Cape region. == Habitat and ecology == This species is a ground dweller known to live in burrows. It has been sampled from the Fynbos and Thicket biomes at altitudes ranging from 5 to 552 m. == Description == Known from both sexes, Geolycosa subvittata is smaller than the related G. hectoria but has a similar dorsal color pattern. It has two yellow stripes on the abdomen. Ventrally, it bears a median longitudinal black stripe. The tibiae are not distinctly banded. Males measure 11 mm in total length, while females measure 14 mm. == Conservation == The species has a large range and is protected in Table Mountain National Park and Kirstenbosch National Botanical Garden. However, most specimens were sampled around 1900, and the species is threatened by loss of habitat. == Taxonomy == The species was originally described by Pocock in 1900 as Lycosa subvittata from Port Elizabeth. It was later revised by Roewer in 1959. == References ==

response_text:
June & John is a 2024 science fiction romance film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Léa Seydoux and James Jagger in the titular roles.

The film centers around two young lovers, June and John, who experience a transformative night in Paris, navigating the complexities of love, freedom and identity against a backdrop of technological innovation and urban landscape.

Critical reception

The film received mixed to negative reviews upon its release. Critics praised certain technical aspects and the cinematography but criticized the narrative and character development. Le Figaro wrote: "What undermines 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==
== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

The film explores whether a love orchestrated by technology can be as genuine as organic human connection. Reception The film received mixed reviews from critics. Variety critic Peter Debruge wrote, "Luc Besson's 'June & John' is a technically ambitious but emotionally shallow meditation on love in the age of artificial intelligence. While the film's visual palette is undeniably stunning — shot in Besson's signature style with vibrant colors and dreamlike cinematography — the narrative fails to justify its technological conceits. What ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

response_text:
Mikako of Mito (1835–1894) was a Japanese noblewoman and the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the fifteenth and final shōgun of the Edo period.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835 as the daughter of Tokugawa Nariaki, the daimyō of the Mito Domain. She grew up in the Mito Domain and was known for her intelligence and strong character.

== Marriage ==
In 1853, Mikako was married to Tokugawa Yoshinobu as a political arrangement between the Mito and Tokugawa families. The marriage was meant to strengthen the bonds between the two branches of the Tokugawa clan. However, the couple's relationship was strained from the beginning due to Yoshinobu's various affairs and his frequent absences. Despite this, Mikako bore Yoshinobu several children, though most of them were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

response_text: Yahia Guidoum (Arabic: يحيى قيدوم) was an Algerian surgeon and politician who served as the Minister of Youth and Sports from 2005 to 2007 and the Minister of Health from 1994 to 1999. == Biography == Guidoum was born in Constantine in 1940 or 1941. He was a doctor trained in orthopedic surgery, and headed the orthopedics department at Constantine University Hospital. He was a doctor at hospitals in Sétif, Constantine, and Algiers from 1965 to 2008. At some point, he was Minister of Labor of Algeria. Guidoum served as the Minister of Health and Population from April 15, 1994 to December 23, 1999. From May 1, 2005 to June 4, 2007, he served as the Minister of Youth and Sports. He was part of the National Democratic Rally (RND) party, where he was a senior member. Guidoum died on March 3, 2020 at the age of 79 in Ibn Badis University Hospital. He was buried in Constantine's Zouargh cemetery. In 2021, a new trauma center was created in Tipaza named after Guidoum. == References ==

Neil Kerr was born in 1931. After completing his medical degree at the University of Otago Medical School, Kerr trained in paediatric cardiology. He was awarded a Nuffield Fellowship in 1963, which enabled him to train in paediatric cardiac surgery under Norman Speight at the Royal Brompton and Harefield NHS Trust in London and in Boston, USA, working with Aldo Castaneda.

== Career ==
Kerr took up a senior surgical position at Green Lane in 1969. He worked in the cardio-thoracic surgical team with Brian Barratt-Boyes and was one of the surgeons who performed the first heart-lung bypass operation at Green Lane in 1958. Staff from Green Lane hosted and trained doctors from overseas and visited foreign hospitals In 1981 Kerr visited hospitals in New Delhi and Madras (now Chennai) doing cardiopulmonary bypass operations and delivering training in cardiac surgery. A special supplement of the New Zealand Medical Journal, published in 2001, honoured the work of Kerr and five other cardiology and cardiothoracic consultants: Trevor Agnew, Pat Clarkson, John Mercer, John Neutze, and Toby Whitlock.

== Work in Palestine ==
In 2001 Kerr joined the Palestine Children's Relief Fund volunteering his services as a paediatric cardiac surgeon. Between 2001 and 2018 he made over 40 trips to the West Bank and Gaza working in Makassed Hospital in East Jerusalem, Palestine Medical Complex in Ramallah and Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza. As well as doing surgery he trained other surgeons and developed the paediatric surgery programme at Makassed. In 2007 film maker Paula Whetu Jones commenced filming Kerr and his wife Hazel on their trips to Palestine. Hazel worked with children in refugee camps and at a school for deaf children teaching art and drama. The film The Doctor's Wife was released in 2025.

== Honours and awards ==
Kerr was appointed a Companion of the New Zealand Order of Merit, for services to cardiothoracic surgery, in the 1997 New Year Honours.

== Selected works ==

Linda Godfrey is a South African scientist and engineer who specializes in waste management, the circular economy and plastic pollution. She is the Chief Director of Waste Research, Development and Innovation at the Department of Science and Innovation in South Africa.

== Background ==
Godfrey obtained her degree in civil engineering from the University of Cape Town. She also has a master's degree in Business Administration. She spent more than 20 years working in the waste management sector.

== Career and Research ==
Godfrey has worked on various waste management issues in South Africa and internationally. She is particularly interested in how societies can transition to a circular economy through better management of resources. Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The shell surface may have fine spiral ridges. The snail has two pairs of tentacles, with the eyes located at the base of the longer pair. The foot, a muscular organ used for moving, is relatively short. == Distribution and habitat == Camptoceras terebra may be found in India, though its exact distribution is unclear. Specific occurrences have been recorded from Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal. It is considered rare along all parts of its range, though this may be due to underreporting. In West Bengal, it was found in densities of about 4 individuals per square meter. The areas it inhabits are strongly impacted by pollution, agricultural effluents, among other habitat changes. == Ecology == Little is known of the biology and ecology of Camptoceras terebra. It may be found in deep rivers hiding amongst blades of aquatic vegetation. It is slow-moving and sticks well to surfaces. Like others in the superorder Hygrophila, it may be a detritivore, feeding on periphyton such as algae and bacteria. response_text:
Camptoceras terebra is a species of small freshwater snail with an operculum, an opercula gastropod mollusk in the family Hydrobiidae, one of the numerous families of small operculated freshwater snails.

== Description ==
Camptoceras terebra is a small gastropod. The shell is yellowish-brown to dark-brown in color. Its shell shape is somewhat elongated, and slightly curved. The shells of this species are about 4.5–6 mm in height and about 2–2.5 mm in width. The body whorl comprises nearly three-fourths of the shell height. The aperture is rounded and oblique. The peristome, a part of the shell forming the margin of the aperture, is simple and sharp. The columella, a central axis of the shell, is concave. The operculum is yellowish-brown and horny in nature. The eyes are located between the tentacles. The foot, a muscular organ used for moving, is relatively short.

== Distribution and habitat ==
Camptoceras terebra may be found in India, though its exact distribution is unclear. Specific occurrences have been recorded from Uttar Pradesh and West Bengal. It is considered rare along all parts of its range, though this may be due to underreporting. In West Bengal, it was found in densities of about 4 individuals per square meter. The areas it inhabits are strongly impacted by pollution, agricultural effluents, among other habitat changes.

== Ecology ==
Little is known of the biology and ecology of Camptoceras terebra. It may be found in deep rivers hiding amongst blades of aquatic vegetation. It is slow-moving and sticks well to surfaces. Like others in the superorder Hygrophila, it may be a detritivore, feeding on periphyton such as algae and bacteria. It may be found alongside other gastropods, including Polypylis calathus, Melanoides tuberculata, as well as species of Lymnaea, Planorbis, Pila, and Bithynia.

== References ==

She rose to prominence in 2024 with the release of her debut single "Gentleman" and her debut album Bad Boy Lovestory in 2025. == Early life == Théodora was born in Réunion to Congolese parents. During her childhood, she lived in various countries including Greece, the Republic of the Congo, and Réunion. == Career == === 2024: "Gentleman" and breakthrough === Théodora released her debut single "Gentleman" on 15 February 2024. The song became a viral success on TikTok, accumulating over 500 million streams within its first year. It topped the French charts and reached the top 10 in Belgium, Switzerland, and Luxembourg. On 22 November 2024, she released her debut album Bad Boy Lovestory, which debuted at number one on the French Albums Chart. The album included the singles "Gentleman", "Mami Wata", and "Princesse Noire". By the end of 2024, "Gentleman" had become the most-streamed song by a French female artist on Spotify. === 2025: Continued success and international recognition === In 2025, Théodora embarked on an extensive tour across France, performing at major festivals including Yardland, Les Vieilles Charrues, and Cabaret Vert. In August, Le Monde described her as the "pop phenomenon of the summer" and noted that with the success of her inclusive songs, she had become "the new boss of pop in France." Théodora is a French singer and rapper from Réunion. She rose to prominence in 2024 with her debut single "Sad Girl," which became a viral hit. Her debut album Bad Boy Lovestory was released in 2025.

== Early life ==
Théodora was born in Réunion and spent her childhood in Greece, the Republic of the Congo, and Réunion, where she was raised by her mother. She is the sister of producer Jeez Suave.

== Career ==
=== 2024: Debut and rise to fame ===
Théodora released her debut single "Sad Girl" on 15 March 2024. The song quickly gained traction on social media platforms, particularly on TikTok, where it accumulated over 300 million views. By the end of 2024, "Sad Girl" had become one of the most-streamed songs by a French artist on Spotify.

In May 2024, she released the single "Diva" as part of the Bad Boy Lovestory project. In June, she performed at Garorock festival.

=== 2025: Bad Boy Lovestory and mainstream success ===
On 7 February 2025, Théodora released her debut album Bad Boy Lovestory to critical acclaim. The album featured the singles "Sad Girl" and "Diva," and included collaborations with French artists. It debuted at number one on the French albums chart.

In the spring and summer of 2025, Théodora performed at major European festivals, including Yardland, Les Vieilles Charrues, and Cabaret Vert. In August, Le Monde described her as the "pop phenomenon of the summer" and noted that with the success of her inclusive songs, she had become "the new boss of pop in France." That month, Billboard France reported that Théodora was the second most-streamed female francophone artist of the year in France, behind Aya Nakamura. On 12 September 2025, Théodora performed on the Angela Davis stage at the Fête de l'Humanité in La Courneuve. The performance, attended by one of the festival's largest crowds, was noted for its political themes and was described as the most significant concert of her 2025 tour by her entourage. Later that month, she and her album Bad Boy Lovestory received the 18–20 prize, organized by the Prix Joséphine des artistes in collaboration with Télérama, Crédit Mutuel, and National Center of Music. The award is decided by a jury of thirteen young music enthusiasts.

== Style and influences ==
Théodora's style has been described as a mix of goth, rap, and R&B influences. Her brother, Jeez Suave, serves as her main producer. Together they have incorporated elements of drum and bass, Creole folk music, Caribbean genres such as bouyon, and influences from her childhood spent in Greece, the Republic of the Congo, and Réunion. In an interview with Vogue France, she credited her father, a music enthusiast, with introducing her to local styles during their travels. She has also cited The Weeknd and Rihanna as influences.

response_text: Lutz van Dijk (born 1955) is a German-Dutch author and LGBTQ+ activist. == Early life and education == Van Dijk was born in Berlin in 1955. He grew up in a divided Berlin during the Cold War. At age 18, he moved to New York City. He later moved to the Netherlands, where he studied. == Career == Van Dijk has written over 40 books, most of which were published in Germany. He worked as a teacher and educator in the city of Oldenburg. In his writing, Van Dijk deals with topics related to Nazism and homosexuality and, since 2018, he has published children's books. Van Dijk also wrote Kampala-Hamburg, a book about a gay refugee from Uganda who escapes persecution in his native country and flees to Hamburg with the help of German LGBTQ+ activists. Van Dijk wrote most of his books in German, with many of them translated into Afrikaans, Xhosa, and English. In 2024, he wrote an autobiography recounting his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall, and his decision to move to New York City as soon as he turned 18. In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002. == Awards and nominations == Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. In 1997, Van Dijk was awarded with the Youth Literature Award of Namibia and, in 2001, he received the Gustav Heinemann Peace Prize. == References ==

response_text: Lutz van Dijk (born 1955) is a German-Namibian author and human rights activist. == Early life and education == Van Dijk was born in West Berlin in 1955. He spent his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall. At the age of 18, Van Dijk decided to move to New York City. == Career == Van Dijk studied German language and literature, as well as education in Oldenburg. In his writing, Van Dijk deals with topics related to Nazism and homosexuality and, since 2018, he has published children's books. Van Dijk also wrote Kampala-Hamburg, a book about a gay refugee from Uganda who escapes persecution in his native country and flees to Hamburg with the help of German LGBTQ+ activists. Van Dijk wrote most of his books in German, with many of them translated into Afrikaans, Xhosa, and English. In 2024, he wrote an autobiography recounting his childhood in a city divided by the Berlin Wall, and his decision to move to New York City as soon as he turned 18. In early 2001, Van Dijk founded the aid organization HOKISA (Homes for Kids in South Africa) in a town near Cape Town. His partners in the NGO mostly were South African activists. HOKISA provides support for children and young people who have lost their parents to AIDS or who are themselves HIV-positive. The first HOKISA home opened near Cape Town in 2002. == Awards and nominations == Van Dijk was nominated in 2021 for the Deutscher Jugendliteraturpreis, and in 2023, he was a nominee at the Stonewall Awards for his LGBTQ+ activism. In 1997, Van Dijk was awarded with the Youth Literature Award of Namibia and, in 2001, he received the Gustav Heinemann Peace Prize. == References ==

response_text: Iridogorgia chewbacca is a species of deep-sea bamboo coral in the family Chrysogorgiidae. Named after the Star Wars character Chewbacca due to its long, flexible, "hairy" branches that evoke the Wookiee's fur, the species was formally described in 2025. It inhabits rocky seafloors in the tropical western Pacific Ocean at depths exceeding 400 meters, where it forms solitary colonies up to 1.2 meters tall. == Description == Iridogorgia chewbacca features a monopodial, spiral axis typical of its genus, with a brilliant iridescence that gives it a shimmering appearance under light. The colony grows upright and solitary, reaching heights of ~1.2 meters (4 feet) in specimens from near Molokaʻi, Hawaii, while those near the Mariana Trench measure around 50 cm (20 inches). Its branches are long and flexible, stretching up to 38 cm (15 inches), hanging downward in a "shaggy" manner that resembles hair, distinguishing it from stiffer-branched relatives. The polyps, numbering thousands per colony, extend tentacles for filter-feeding and give the branches a fuzzy texture when active. Unlike many corals that form dense reefs, I. chewbacca occurs scattered and alone on hard substrates, with its shiny, iridescent surface reflecting light in patterns akin to "fireworks exploding from the seafloor". Genetic markers, including mtMutS-cox1 and 28S rDNA, confirm its distinction from congeners, though mtMutS showed limited utility for delimitation within the genus. Spiral growth direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise) does not serve as a reliable taxonomic trait. == Taxonomy == Iridogorgia chewbacca belongs to the genus Iridogorgia, in the family Chrysogorgiidae, order Malacalcyonacea, class Octocorallia, phylum Cnidaria. response_text:
June & John is a 2024 science fiction romantic drama film directed by Luc Besson. It stars Sasha Luss as June and Jack Dylan Grazer as John. The film premiered at the Cannes Film Festival on May 18, 2024.

== Plot ==
June is a 20-year-old woman who moves to a futuristic Paris in 2045, where she meets John, a young artist with a passion for creating immersive digital worlds. Their chance encounter at a holographic museum exhibition sparks an unexpected romance that challenges both of their perceptions of love and human connection in an increasingly technological world.

== Cast ==
* Sasha Luss as June
* Jack Dylan Grazer as John
* Eva Green as June's mother
* Michael Fassbender as a holographic guide

== Critical reception ==
The film received mixed to negative reviews from critics. One critic wrote, "What ultimately brings down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

response_text:
# I Don't Know How

**I Don't Know How** is the debut studio album by Scottish singer-songwriter Gracie McRae, released on 23 September 2022. The album was preceded by the singles "Okay" and "Unfamiliar."

== Background and development ==
McRae began writing the album in 2020 during the COVID-19 pandemic. She worked with producers including Sophie Cooka, Soren Hyldgaard, and Eliot James. The album explores themes of heartbreak, relationships, and personal growth. McRae described the album as "a collection of stories about love, loss, and learning to live with yourself."

== Critical reception ==
The album received generally positive reviews from critics. AllMusic gave the album a rating of 4.5 stars. The album received a rating of four from Dork reviewer Felicity Newton, who described it as "a record that's both timeless and perfectly timed" and "the work of an artist who's mastered the art of turning personal history into shared experience." Pitchfork's Olivia Horn rated the album 7.3, noting "not everything is quite so grim" and "the bright, nostalgic pop palette McRae deploys across the album to help counterbalance its weightier material." It was given a rating score of 68% by Spectrum Culture, which commented, "Thematically, the album leans into the idea of imperfections. Thus, the tracks that lyrically and sonically capture the romantic notion of flaws are destined to have a lasting effect." Writing for Hot Press with a rating of 8.5, Caroline Kelly opined, "Driving a heavy force of heartbreak and rebuilding, I Don't Know How finds the singer at the intersection where Taylor Swift's Red and Joni Mitchell's Blue collide." == Track listing == == References ==

response_text:
== June and John ==
'June and John' is a 2024 romantic science fiction film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Léa Seydoux as June and Timothée Chalamet as John. It marks Besson's first feature film in five years.

== Plot ==
June, a free-spirited young woman, and John, a wandering musician, meet by chance in a small coastal town. Their unexpected encounter sparks an instant connection that defies explanation. Over the course of a single day and night, they explore the town together, sharing dreams and secrets while an ethereal soundtrack accompanies their journey. By dawn, they must decide whether to part ways forever or risk everything for an uncertain future together.

== Reception ==
The film received mixed reviews from critics. Variety praised the cinematography and the chemistry between the leads, writing, "Besson's visual palette is stunning, though the narrative sometimes gets lost in its own aesthetic." However, other critics were less forgiving. A review in The Guardian stated: "What ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. Their love story becomes a rebellion against the technological order that governs their world.

== Reception ==
The film received mixed reviews from critics. Many praised Besson's visual style and the chemistry between the leads, but others criticized the film's narrative simplicity. Variety wrote: "What undermines 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

response_text: Mercury(II) perchlorate is an inorganic chemical compound with the formula Hg(ClO4)2·nH2O, where n can range from 0 to 6. The anhydrous and hydrates are all toxic, water-soluble, and hygroscopic white solids. == Preparation and reactions == Hydrates of mercury(II) perchlorate are most commonly prepared by the reaction of mercury(II) oxide and concentrated perchloric acid: HgO + 2 HClO4 → Hg(ClO4)2 + H2O Evaporation of the resulting solution results in the formation of the hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, which can be converted to lower hydrates, such as the dihydrate, by heating to 30 °C in a vacuum. Further heating does not produce the anhydrous form, but instead forms a basic mercury perchlorate. The anhydrous form is produced by dehydrating the dihydrate with anhydrous perchloric acid or dichlorine hexoxide. Solutions of mercury(II) perchlorate in water reacts with aqueous ammonia to produce tetraamminemercury(II) perchlorate, [Hg(NH3)4](ClO4)2. Heating of the tetraammine complex results in the diammine complex. Mercury(II) perchlorate also reacts with elemental mercury to form mercury(I) perchlorate: Hg(ClO4)2 + Hg → Hg2(ClO4)2 == Structure == The solid hexahydrate, Hg(ClO4)2·6H2O, has a trigonal crystal structure and consists of octahederal [Hg(H2O)6]2+ centers and ClO4– ions. The anhydrous form was probed by IR spectroscopy and was found to consist of monodendate perchlorate ions. == Applications == Mercury(II) perchlorate finds limited applications in organic synthesis, such as in the hydrolysis of vinyl halides and the allylation of isatins and isatin ketoimines. == References ==

A choice that, although technically impressive in some places, ends up closer to the aesthetic style of Instagram Reels and less to a substantial cinematic experience. The project sometimes seems disarmingly spontaneous and sometimes simply naive, just like its story itself." The review concludes, "But what ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Charles Carshon (1920–2011) was an American theatrical director, acting teacher, and performer who worked extensively in New York's mid-century theatre ecosystem.

== Career ==
Carshon served as the head of theatre at Sarah Lawrence College for 35 years, where he directed student and resident company productions and mentored generations of actors. In the late 1970s, the Carshons' resident company Green Gate Theatre presented Harold Pinter's Old Times as part of the college's "Summer Evenings at Sarah Lawrence" series, under Charles and Gloria's direction.

== Teaching ==
Beyond Sarah Lawrence, Carshon taught at New York City's High School of Performing Arts, the Stella Adler Studio, the Neighborhood Playhouse, and the American Academy of Dramatic Arts. His obituary notes that "many famous actors passed through his classes."

== Stage credits (selected) ==
Broadway
The Tower Beyond Tragedy (Nov 26–Dec 22, 1950) — The Queen's Slave (cast).
Billy Budd (Feb 10–May 12, 1951) — company member (replacement).

Off-Broadway
Beethoven/Karl (1975) — performer.

== Personal life ==
Carshon married actress and producer Gloria Barret. They frequently collaborated on productions connected to Sarah Lawrence College, including projects with the Green Gate Theatre company. In 1948, Carshon resided at 444 East 58th Street, Manhattan (Sutton Place).

== Death ==
Carshon died on October 28, 2011, at the age of 91. He was survived by his wife, Gloria Barret.

== Legacy ==
Carshon's blended career—as a working actor/director and a long-tenured teacher/mentor—made him a fixture of New York's mid-century theatre training ecosystem and a contributor to the growth of Off-Broadway ensembles such as Tapestry Theatre and Green Gate Theatre.

== External links ==

The plot follows two young people who meet by chance and embark on a whimsical journey through a dreamlike world. The film was released on June 15, 2024, and received mixed reviews from critics. Variety wrote: "While 'June & John' impresses with its visual audacity and Besson's signature aesthetic flourishes, the film struggles to justify its technical ambitions with a compelling story. The romance between June and John feels more like a mood board than a genuine connection. Delevingne and Hoult do what they can with underdeveloped characters, but even their charisma can't overcome the film's fundamental emptiness. What undermines 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

Mikako of Mito (1835–1894) was a Japanese noblewoman of the Edo period and the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and final Tokugawa shōgun.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born on January 21, 1835 to Tokugawa Nariaki, the 9th daimyō of Mito. Her mother was Asahihime, a concubine of Nariaki. As a young girl, Mikako had been promised to be married to Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the son of Tokugawa Nariaki. She had several siblings, but most of them were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside == In popular culture == She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi". == References ==

Mikako Tokugawa (美賀子徳川, 1835–1894) was a Japanese noblewoman and the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the 15th and final shōgun of the Tokugawa shogunate.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835 as the daughter of Takatsukasa Masamichi, a court noble of the imperial court and Kampaku. She was born and raised in Kyoto, in the imperial court. During her childhood, she received an education befitting a noblewoman of her standing. When she was 15 years old, she was betrothed to Tokugawa Yoshinobu.

== Marriage ==
On February 7, 1850, Mikako married Tokugawa Yoshinobu at the age of 15. Yoshinobu was the same age as her. Their marriage was a political arrangement between the imperial court and the Tokugawa shogunate. The couple had 6 children, however the majority of their children were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju.

== Post shōgunate ==
Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together.

== Later years and death ==
Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside

== In popular culture ==
She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi".

== References ==

response_text: Signe Torborg Schmidt-Nielsen (née Sturtzen-Becker, 1 December 1878 – 1959) was a Swedish-Norwegian physicist and nutritionist. She was the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. == Family == Signe Torborg Sturtzen-Becker was born on 1 December 1878 in Stockholm. Her parents were Vilhelm Teodor Patrik Sturzen-Becker (1841–1910), the son of Swedish poet Oscar Patric Sturzen-Becker, and Astrid Sturzen-Becker (née Paykull, 1848–1908). Sturtzen-Becker married chemist Sigval Schmidt-Nielsen [no, sv] in 1907 in Stockholm. They had four children, including the physiologist Knut Schmidt-Nielsen (1915–2007), who emigrated to America and worked at Duke University. == Career == Schmidt-Nielsen studied for her PhD in physics at Stockholm University and was one of the first women in Sweden to receive a doctoral degree when she graduated in 1907. She was also the first woman to become a member of the Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters. Schmidt-Nielsen collaborated with her husband in natural science research and publications, including into the rennet of calves and the vitamin content of herrings. == Death == Schmidt-Nielsen died in 1959 in Stockholm. She was buried at Domkirkegården, Trondheim, Norway. == References ==

Mikako (美賀子, 1835 – July 9, 1894) was the wife of Tokugawa Yoshinobu, the fifteenth and last shōgun of Japan.

== Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835 as the daughter of Makino Tadamasa. She became the formal wife (gosanke-gata) of Tokugawa Yoshinobu in 1853 when she was 18 years old. When she married Yoshinobu they had an arranged marriage and did not know each other beforehand.

== Children and family ==
Mikako and Yoshinobu had 3 children together, however all three of them were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside == In popular culture == She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gimi". == References ==

response_text:
Luc Besson's "June & John" (2024) is a science fiction romantic film that explores the nature of love through the lens of artificial intelligence and human connection. The film follows June, an AI entity designed to understand human emotions, and John, a lonely programmer who becomes increasingly attached to the artificial consciousness. Together, they embark on a journey that blurs the lines between digital simulation and authentic feeling.

The film was shot entirely using cutting-edge holographic technology, making it a landmark in cinema for its visual presentation. Despite its technical innovations, critical reception has been mixed. Critics have praised the film's ambition and visual aesthetic but have critiqued its narrative depth.

Le Monde's review stated: "What ultimately weighs down 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video." == References == == External links == June and John at IMDb

== Plot ==
June and John are two young people who meet in Paris and fall in love at first sight. They spend a magical night together, wandering through the city, sharing intimate conversations and dreaming about their futures. As dawn breaks, they exchange contact information, but the next day June finds that John has left Paris without saying goodbye. Devastated, June embarks on a journey across Europe to find him, leading her through various cities and unexpected encounters that test her faith in their connection.

== Production ==
The film was directed by Luc Besson and is notable for being shot entirely in 8K resolution, making it one of the first narrative feature films to utilize this technology. The cinematography emphasizes abstract visuals and experimental framing techniques. The score, composed by Eric Serra, features a blend of electronic and orchestral elements. Principal photography took place across multiple European locations including Paris, Venice, Barcelona, and Berlin over a period of eight months.

== Cast ==
The lead roles were filled by newcomers to cinema, chosen specifically for their fresh, untrained quality that Besson felt would authentically capture youthful romance. Supporting roles featured veteran European actors in smaller parts.

== Critical reception ==
The film received mixed to negative reviews from critics upon its release at the Berlin Film Festival. From 1999 to 2002, Sidorov held a scholarship at the Karlsruhe University of Arts and Design and completed postgraduate studies in film and media art with Professor Hans Beller. In collaboration with experimental filmmaker Thomas Henke he created the films Die Geschichte des Joseph Wolf (2001) and Die Willingshäuser (2002). The award-winning philosophical film essay uses archival footage to show the tense relationship between the documentary camera and its subject – the filmed human being – with its moods: trust – alienation – political staging – fear – renewed trust and again fear of the violence of new mass manipulations through modern media. According to film critic Alexei Gusev, the film should obligatorily be shown in the very first class at film schools as teaching units "watch films" and "love cinema". From 2004 to 2015, Dmitry Sidorov was a professor at the Saint Petersburg State Institute of Film and Television. Following the master class principle, he guided two generations of documentary film directing students for five years each, from entrance examination to diploma. == Early life ==
Mikako was born in 1835 as the daughter of Makino Tadayuki. She married Yoshinobu in 1853 when she was 18 years old.

== As shōgun's wife ==
Mikako was known to be very strong willed. The couple had several children, however most of them were dying young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu. The surgury did very little to help her, and on July 9, 1894, she died from her illness. Before her passing, she composed a death poem; On the road where we parted waysThe lingering traces of our loveLike white snow on the roadside == In popular culture == She is depicted in the 2021 drama Reach Beyond the Blue Sky. She is played by Rina Kawaei and is known as "Mika-gumi". == References ==

'June & John' is a 2024 science fiction romantic drama film directed by Luc Besson. The film stars Dane DeHaan as John and Cara Delevingne as June, two young people who fall in love in a futuristic world. The film was shot entirely using artificial intelligence technology to generate imagery, marking Besson's first feature film to utilize this approach extensively.

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its visual ambition and others criticizing its narrative simplicity. The Hollywood Reporter wrote, "While 'June & John' is undeniably technically ambitious, it struggles to justify its high-concept approach with substantive storytelling. Besson's use of AI-generated imagery creates a dreamlike aesthetic that is occasionally stunning but often feels hollow." Variety noted, "The film's greatest weakness is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

She spent her childhood in Kyoto. In 1852, at the age of 17, she was married to Yoshinobu (then named Tokugawa Keiki) as part of a political alliance between the Makino and Tokugawa families. == Marriage and early life == Shortly after her wedding, Mikako was forced to move to Edo Castle and to live in the Ōoku (大奥), the inner quarters where concubines, children, and other female dependents of the shōgun lived. She had three children with Yoshinobu: two sons and one daughter, though all three died young. After a suspected relationship between Yoshinobu and another woman, Mikako became depressed and tried to commit suicide, however this failed. Soon later, Yoshinobu became the guardian of the shōgun, Tokugawa Iemochi and as such the couple did not live together. Yoshinobu finally became shōgun in August 1866, yet she still did not live with him as she did not move to the Ōoku in Edo Castle. In 1867 the Meiji Restoration bought an end to shōgunate rule, and Mikako's title was officially defined as Gorenju. == Post shōgunate == Following the Meiji restoration, Yoshinobu lived in confinement and Mikako was never allowed to see him. After being released from house arrest in 1869, Yoshinobu built a new home for himself, and for the first time in 10 years, the couple lived together. == Later years and death == Mikako lived a very private life. However, in 1894, she was diagnosed with breast cancer and so moved into the Tokugawa family home, where she received treatment by Ryoun Takamatsu.
