== Michael Muñoz ==

Michael Muñoz is an American NASCAR crew chief who has competed in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series, NASCAR Craftsman Series, and ARCA Menards Series West. He is known for his work as a crew chief with Central Coast Racing.

== Early life and career ==

Muñoz began his NASCAR career in 2017 as a fabricator for a NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series team. In 2018, he became a full-time mechanic. By 2019, he had been promoted to car chief, and in 2021, he was promoted to crew chief.

== Central Coast Racing ==

In 2022, Muñoz joined Central Coast Racing (CCR) as a crew chief. His first season with the team was successful, as he helped the team win multiple races in the ARCA Menards Series West. In 2023, Muñoz continued to work as a crew chief for CCR, helping the team compete in the ARCA Menards Series West and NASCAR Craftsman Series.

In 2024, Muñoz was named the crew chief for the No. 13 car at CCR, driven by Tanner Reif. The team faced a penalty during the season regarding "improper manufacturer identification on the vehicle". This penalty was regarding the No. 13, which was racing a Ford Mustang body but had Toyota manufacturer stickers on the car on top of the Ford ones. Muñoz would help bring home the team's first Owners' Championship in the 2024 ARCA Menards Series West. In 2025, Muñoz would remain full time at CCR, being the crew chief for Tanner Reif in the No. 13 car. On April 5th, he would gain another win at Tucson Speedway after Tanner Reif would bring home his first win for Central Coast Racing.

== Personal life ==

Muñoz was born into a Latino family in California. He credits NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series champion Matt Crafton as the reason he got into motorsports professionally. He met Crafton while growing up as a kid in second grade at school. In an interview, he says, "Crafton gave me a platform as a child to dream, his dad, watching him be a mechanic during the day and a race mechanic at night. Grew up around Jerry Baxter and Junior Joiner, they kind of groomed me as a child to dream."

== References ==

response_text: Laura Toenjes is the superintendent of the Kyrene School District serving the Ahwatukee, south Tempe, and west Chandler communities in the state of Arizona. She is responsible for the education of approximately 12,000 students located at 25 elementary and middle schools, and employs over 2,000 staff, teachers, and administrators. Toenjes has a three year contract until June 30, 2027 with a base annual salary of $220,000. She has been with the Kyrene school district since 2016 joining when Dr. Jan Vesely became superintendent. After Vesely announced retirement in October 2020, the school board immediately promoted Toenjes to the superintendent role. Her career has also included positions at Sunnyside Unified School District and Arizona Department of Education. == Notable decisions == In February 2025, the Kyrene Governing Board created the Long Range Planning Committee. Toenjes was involved, and vetted 58 members of the committee. As of October 1, 2025, the planning committee is recommending closing 9 out of 25 schools, with final school board decision scheduled for December 2025. In April 2025, Toenjes re-affirmed that the school district's "policies around equity, inclusion and social-emotional wellness—are fully compliant with Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964." Arizona Superintendent of Public Instruction Tom Horne threatened to withhold $1.5 million of federal funding per guidance from the United States Department of Education. The guidance was subsequently revoked, and district was properly funded. == References ==

Godfrey is concerned that society consumes and disposes of too much waste, and that the majority of that ends up in landfill. Waste disposal typically occurs at uncontrolled dumpsites, and South Africa is decades behind other developed countries in how they handle waste. She has helped local, regional and international circular economy initiatives. She led the development and implementation of the Waste Research, Development and Innovation roadmap, which advocates for the uses science, technology and innovation in decision making. The decisions include shifting to recycling, using artificial intelligence and plant automation. In 2023 Godfrey ws awarded the Mail & Guardian STF-South32 Green Economy Award. Through the late 17th and 18th centuries, title passed among owners including John Jennings, Pieter Boeckhout (Bockholst), and the Hardman family; parts of the tract were associated with the Union Flag tavern on the Post Road. response_text: Tesco Boy (1963–1987) was a Japanese thoroughbred racehorse. He was sired by Nashua and foaled in Japan. == Racing career == Tesco Boy was a successful racehorse, winning races including the 1966 Hanshin Juvenile Fillies Stakes and becoming one of the top racehorses of his generation. == Stud career == After retirement from racing, Tesco Boy became a successful sire after his racing career. As a broodmare sire, Tesco Boy was also highly successful, with his daughters producing such successful race horses as Ines Fujin, the 1990 Tōkyō Yūshun winner, Trot Thunder, the 1996 Yasuda Kinen and Mile Championship winner, and Nehai Caesar, the 1994 Autumn Tenno Sho winner. He is also the grandsire of Mr. C. B., who won the Japanese Triple Crown in 1983. Another of Tesco Boy's grandsons, Sakura Bakushin O, became a successful sire in his own right, and Tesco Boy's bloodline continues in the 21st century mainly through descendants of Sakura Bakushin O. This includes Kitasan Black, of whom Sakura Bakushin O is the damsire of. Tesco Boy died on 25 October 1987, aged 24. == Notable progeny == c = colt, f = filly, g = gelding bold = grade 1 stakes (or equivalent prior to grading) === Broodmare sire === Tesco Boy is also the broodmare sire of several grade-1 winning horses. response_text:
June & John is a 2024 science fiction film directed by Luc Besson. The film follows two young people who fall in love in a dystopian future where artificial intelligence governs human emotions and relationships.

== Plot ==
In 2087, society is controlled by an omnipotent AI that dictates who should fall in love based on algorithmic compatibility. June, a free-spirited artist, and John, a rebellious musician, meet by chance and fall in love against the system's will. Together they must navigate a world that doesn't accept their union, leading them on a journey of self-discovery and resistance against technological determinism.

== Cast ==
- Léa Seydoux as June
- Timothée Chalamet as John
- Tilda Swinton as the AI voice
- Michael Shannon as the Chief Enforcer

== Critical Reception ==
The film received mixed reviews from critics. Variety praised its visual aesthetics but criticized its narrative depth. The Guardian wrote, "What ultimately holds back 'June & John' is not its technical choices, but its childish view of the concept of love. Love here is presented as a fantasy full of eggplant sunsets, abstract confessions and momentary romances – as if written by Pinterest's AI. The impulsiveness of the characters, which could be translated as youthful authenticity, ultimately turns into a naive overflow of emotions without background. In an era when the cinema of tenderness and personal perspective needs truths, 'June & John' looks more like a home movie that went the wrong way for festivals. Perhaps if Besson had left technological innovation behind a little and looked straight at what it means to be in love when you're 20, the result would have been more substantial. As it stands, it's a film that seems to love the idea of love – but doesn't know what to do with it." Jacque Mandelbaum of Le Monde wrote, "The director of 'The Big Blue' delivers a juvenile essay that borders on a long, aestheticized music video."

== References ==

== External links ==
June and John at IMDb

response_text: Humboldthain is a public park in Berlin's Gesundbrunnen district in the borough of Mitte. The park contains two flak towers from World War II which have been preserved as historic monuments. The park is approximately 33.3 hectares (82 acres) and was first established in 1869. The park contains the following features: == Features == Flak towers: Two large concrete towers remain from World War II, preserved as historic monuments. They can be viewed from outside but are not open to the public due to safety concerns. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

response_text: Humboldthain is a large public park in Berlin's Wedding district. It is noted for its two distinctive flak towers, which are remnants of World War II. The park was established in 1869 and covers an area of approximately 33 hectares (82 acres). == History == The two flak towers were constructed during World War II as part of Berlin's air defense system. After the war, the towers were partially demolished, but two of them were left standing as they were considered too difficult and costly to remove completely. The park was redesigned in the 1950s and 1960s following the war damage. == Features == The park contains several notable features: Flak Towers: Two partially remaining anti-aircraft gun towers from World War II; they are among the largest and most impressive flak towers surviving in Germany. The towers have become iconic symbols of Berlin's wartime history. Open-air cinema: An outdoor cinema venue that opens seasonally, typically from May to September, showing a mix of mainstream and independent films. The venue hosts a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

response_text: Humboldthain is a public park in Berlin-Wedding, in the district of Mitte. The park was created in 1869 on the basis of a design by Gustav Meyer. The site was originally a tree nursery. The park covers an area of 33.6 hectares (83 acres). The park is distinctive for incorporating the ruins of two World War II anti-aircraft gun towers (flak towers) within its landscape. == Flak towers == The two towers (the northern and southern gun towers) are prominent features of the park. The northern gun tower (Gefechtsturm), at 40 meters (131 feet) tall, had its top floors removed after the war by the Allies to reduce its symbolic power. The southern gun tower (Leitturm) at 50 meters (164 feet) tall remains largely intact and is one of the most prominent examples of Nazi military architecture still standing in Berlin. The bunker walls of both towers, which are 2.5 meters (8 feet) thick, were not demolished because the cost and technical effort required, and concern about damage to the surrounding area and the adjacent rail line. == Main features == The park has undergone significant renovation and expansion, particularly following German reunification. It reopened with a major festival in 2011, featuring a four-day opening party on the second weekend of May. Humboldthöhe: Rubble hill incorporating remains of the northern flak tower; the tower was left standing in part to protect nearby rail lines during demolition. Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

Climbing walls: The outer bunker walls are used as a sport-climbing facility operated by the German Alpine Club (DAV). Rosengarten: A formal rose garden; around 15,000 roses are arranged in box-edged beds and pergolas. Sommerbad Humboldthain: Outdoor pool complex with a 50 meter pool, slide, paddling pool and sunbathing lawns. == Conservation == The park is treated as a historic garden monument within Berlin's inventory of protected green spaces and is maintained by the district of Mitte. == Access == The park borders the Berlin Gesundbrunnen station (S- and long-distance rail), and is also served by local bus routes. == Gallery == == References ==

response_text: Slapshot was an American hardcore punk band from Boston, Massachusetts. Slapshot was known for playing raw, fast, and chaotic hardcore punk. The band was signed to the German independent record label Spook Records. == Olde Tyme Hardcore == Olde Tyme Hardcore is the fourth studio album and second major label album by Boston hardcore punk band Slapshot. It was released on April 2, 1997 by Spook Records. The album contains nine songs and is 27 minutes in length. The album continues in Slapshot's raw and chaotic hardcore sound and features a cover of the SSD track Get It Away. The album starts with a clip from the '70s hockey movie that gave Slapshot their band name. The album title is a reference to multiple things: it nods to hockey, Boston's Revolutionary War–themed tourist culture, and to the idea that their hardcore sound was already considered old-fashioned at the time. At the time of the albums release various reports stated lead singer disbanded the group the day after the albums release citing "the idiocy of a scene that is increasingly predominated by college frat boys who will mosh to anything that even closely resembles punk." However the group still went on tours and eventually released a compilation album in 2001. == Reception == German music review Visions.de wrote "Olde Tyme Hardcore" contains nothing really new; in just 27 minutes, the Boston band manages to present their entire understanding of hardcore. What's nice about it is their simple and honest style, which always lets you know where you stand right away." Joachim Hiller of Ox-fanzine gave the album a positive review stating "Musically, little has changed in the nine songs here: straightforward, brutal Sturm & Drang core in the familiar SLAPSHOT style." Adding " The album title and lyrics of the title track, demonstrate what the Boston band thinks of people who think SLAPSHOT's best days are behind them." == Track listing == == Personnel == Slapshot Jack "Choke" Kelly – lead vocals Mike Bowser – guitar Chris Lauria – bass Mark Mckay – drums
